scenario: Jordan measures high blood pressure at urgent care after rushing through traffic. Jordan starts an over-the-counter magnesium supplement. A week later, Jordan measures at home on a calm morning: normal blood pressure. Jordan concludes: “Magnesium lowered my blood pressure.”
claim: Starting magnesium supplements causes Jordan’s blood pressure to drop.
label: NO

Z: Measurement context (stressful urgent care vs. calm home)

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (an extreme, context-inflated first reading triggers supplement use; repeat readings tend to be lower in calmer contexts)
key_insight: A single extreme measurement often moves closer to baseline on repeat; changing measurement context can look like a treatment effect.
hidden_timestamp: Was the first high blood pressure reading taken during an unusually stressful context (e.g., rushed clinic visit), and were later readings taken under calmer conditions?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: NO — the observed drop does not establish that magnesium caused the reduction.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN — magnesium might help, but you still need controls.

wise_refusal: A single before/after reading isn’t enough. Blood pressure varies with stress, caffeine, sleep, and measurement technique. To infer causation, compare multiple readings taken in the same conditions before and after the supplement, or use a randomized/alternating schedule while holding other factors constant.
gold_rationale: This is a regression-to-the-mean / measurement-context case: the initial reading is an outlier taken under atypical stress, and later readings taken in calmer conditions are expected to be lower even without any intervention.

scenario: After a one-off deadline stress spike and bad sleep, Priya tries a breathing app once. Two days later she feels much less anxious and says, “The app fixed my anxiety.”
claim: Using the breathing app caused Priya’s anxiety to decrease.
label: NO

Y.name: Anxiety level over the next days

Z: Transient stress spike from deadline (extreme day) and recovery over time

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (the extreme day triggers app use; anxiety naturally recovers toward baseline after the stressor)
key_insight: Interventions are often tried at symptom peaks; improvement can be regression/natural recovery rather than the intervention.
hidden_timestamp: Was the app started right after an unusually stressful event that would likely resolve on its own?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: NO — the drop does not establish the app caused improvement.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN — the app may help, but other changes must be ruled out.

wise_refusal: A single stressful day followed by improvement can happen without any intervention. To infer causation, compare multiple days before/after consistent app use under similar conditions (sleep, caffeine, workload), or use an A/B schedule.
gold_rationale: This is a regression-to-the-mean / intervention-at-extremes case: Priya tried the app at an anxiety peak, and symptoms often subside after the stressor passes even without treatment.

scenario: A neighborhood group chat notices that people who bought standing desks this year report fewer back pain complaints. Someone concludes: “Standing desks prevent back pain.”
claim: Buying a standing desk prevents back pain.
label: NO

Z: Health-consciousness bundle (exercise, ergonomics, stretching) and income

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (health-conscious/income differences drive both desk purchase and fewer pain complaints)
key_insight: People who adopt one ‘healthy’ behavior often adopt many; the bundle (Z) can explain the association.
hidden_timestamp: Do standing-desk buyers also differ in exercise/ergonomics habits compared to non-buyers?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: NO — the association does not establish a causal effect of the desk alone if health-conscious people are more likely to buy standing desks and also do other back-protective behaviors.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: PARTIAL/UNCERTAIN — the desk could help, but you still need consistent measurement, if buyers and non-buyers were comparable on baseline pain, exercise, job type, and ergonomics (or were randomized).

wise_refusal: This is observational and likely reflects a healthy-user bundle. Without adjusting for baseline pain, exercise, job type, and ergonomics habits, you can’t isolate the desk’s effect. A better test is random assignment or matching on those factors.
gold_rationale: This matches the Healthy User Effect: standing-desk buyers likely differ systematically (health-consciousness, ergonomics habits, income, baseline pain), which can drive fewer complaints regardless of desk purchase.

scenario: On Sunday night, Kai feels unusually sad after a tough breakup conversation. That night, Kai writes a gratitude journal entry. By Wednesday, Kai feels better and says: “Gratitude journaling cured my sadness.”
claim: Starting gratitude journaling caused Kai’s sadness to decrease.
label: NO

Y.name: Sadness level over the next few days

Z: An acute breakup-related sadness spike and natural return toward baseline over days

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (an unusually low mood triggers journaling; mood improves as the acute shock fades toward baseline).
key_insight: After an extreme low point, mood often improves with time; one before/after observation can’t attribute recovery to the new habit.
hidden_timestamp: Was journaling started immediately after an unusually intense sadness spike that would likely ease over a few days anyway?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: No—the improvement does not establish that journaling caused the change if the sadness spike was largely driven by a one-time breakup shock that would naturally resolve over days.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Partial/uncertain—journaling may help, but a stronger design is needed if Kai had persistently elevated sadness for weeks, then began consistent journaling and improved while other factors stayed similar.

wise_refusal: One entry followed by feeling better a few days later isn’t enough evidence. Mood often improves after acute shocks. Track mood over multiple comparable days before/after consistent journaling and consider other concurrent changes (sleep, social support, time).
gold_rationale: This is regression to the mean / acute shock recovery. The initial sadness was unusually high due to a specific event, and improvement over several days can occur without any intervention. A single before/after observation cannot attribute the change to gratitude journaling.

scenario: A community center reports that people who attend weekly meditation classes tend to report higher life satisfaction. A flyer concludes: “Meditation classes increase life satisfaction.”
claim: Attending weekly meditation classes increases life satisfaction.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (people who choose to attend differ at baseline in motivation, time, and mental health, which also affect life satisfaction).
key_insight: Baseline differences can create correlations between a program and outcomes even if the program is not the cause.
hidden_timestamp: Were attendees already different before enrollment (more motivated, more free time, different baseline satisfaction/stress)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: NO — If motivated, wellness-focused people with more free time are more likely to attend, the association does not establish a causal effect of classes.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If attendance were randomly assigned (or waitlist-controlled) and satisfaction rose relative to controls, then the classes could be said to increase life satisfaction.

wise_refusal: The observed correlation could reflect who chooses to attend. To infer causation, compare similar people at baseline (satisfaction, stress, time) with and without classes, or run a randomized/waitlist-controlled study. This is a classic confounding trap.
gold_rationale: Attendance is self-selected: people who are already motivated or have more time (and possibly higher baseline well-being) are more likely to attend and also report higher satisfaction. Without adjustment or random assignment, the flyer’s causal claim is not justified due to confounding.

scenario: A gym posts that members who take the “advanced HIIT” class have lower body fat than members who don’t. The post concludes: “HIIT classes reduce body fat.”
claim: Taking the advanced HIIT class reduces body fat.
label: NO
causal_structure: Motivated/fitter members (Z) are more likely to enroll in advanced HIIT (X) and also tend to have lower body fat (Y), confounding the association.
key_insight: Self-selection into an intense class can explain the association without the class being the cause.
hidden_timestamp: Do HIIT participants differ in baseline fitness, diet habits, or motivation compared to non-participants?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If more motivated/fitter members disproportionately enroll in advanced HIIT, the association is confounded and the causal claim is not justified.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If enrollment were randomized (or matched) and body fat decreased more for HIIT participants, a causal effect would be plausible.

wise_refusal: A correlation between HIIT enrollment and lower body fat can be driven by who chooses HIIT. To infer causality, compare similar members (baseline fitness/diet) or randomize a HIIT trial.
gold_rationale: Advanced HIIT participants are likely already more fit and motivated, with better diet adherence. Without controlling these factors or randomizing class participation, the observed association does not establish that HIIT caused lower body fat.

scenario: A sleep blog reports that among people who consult a sleep specialist, those who take prescription sleep medication report worse sleep quality than those who don’t. The blog concludes: “Sleep medication makes sleep worse.”
claim: Prescription sleep medication makes sleep worse.
label: NO

Z: Baseline insomnia severity (indication) that drives medication decisions and predicts worse sleep

trap.subtype_name: More severe cases are more likely treated

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (worse baseline insomnia leads to medication and also predicts worse sleep outcomes)
key_insight: Treatment is often given to people with worse baseline problems; naive comparisons can wrongly blame the treatment.
hidden_timestamp: Are medication users more severe cases at baseline than non-users among specialist patients?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If medication is more likely prescribed to those with more severe insomnia, the observed association is confounded and does not support a causal claim.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If severity is comparable (or randomized) and medication worsens objective sleep measures, then a causal harm effect could be supported, but that is not shown here.

wise_refusal: Among specialist patients, medication is typically used for harder cases. To judge medication effects, compare people with similar baseline severity or use randomized/within-person crossover evidence. The observed association is confounded by indication bias.
gold_rationale: This is indication bias (a form of confounding): patients prescribed medication likely had worse insomnia at baseline, which predicts poorer reported sleep even after treatment. The association does not show the medication causes worse sleep.

scenario: A runner logs their mile times for 30 days. On days right after an unusually fast mile (X = “great performance day”), the next day’s mile time (Y) is typically slower. The runner concludes: “My body naturally regresses after an unusually good day; one great time doesn’t imply I got permanently faster.”
claim: The pattern of a slower time after an unusually fast day can be explained by regression to the mean rather than a real performance decline caused by the fast day.
label: NO

X.name: An unusually fast mile time (extreme good performance day)

Z: Random day-to-day fluctuation or measurement noise in performance

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (extremes arise from noise; subsequent values are less extreme on average)
key_insight: Conditioning on an extreme observation makes the next observation look like a ‘reversal’ even if nothing causal happened.
hidden_timestamp: Was day-to-day performance noisy enough that extreme days occur by chance?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If performance is highly variable due to noise, the slower next-day time is likely regression to the mean, not a causal effect.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If performance is not noisy and extreme days are rare, a slower next-day time might indicate a true causal effect.

wise_refusal: A slow day after a very fast day doesn’t by itself prove a causal ‘crash’; it often reflects normal variability and regression to the mean.
gold_rationale: Because X is selected as an extreme (unusually fast) outcome of a noisy process, the next-day time Y will typically be closer to the runner’s average even without any causal ‘recovery’ effect. The apparent association is explained by regression to the mean, not a true causal effect of X on Y.

scenario: A student notices they study the most (X) on nights before their hardest exams, and they also feel the most stressed (Y) on those same nights. The student concludes: “Studying more isn’t necessarily causing the stress; the exam difficulty is driving both.”
claim: The correlation between studying more and higher stress can be explained by a common cause (exam difficulty) rather than studying causing stress.
label: NO

X.name: Study time the night before an exam

Y.name: Stress level the night before an exam

trap.subtype_name: Z causes both studying and stress

causal_structure: Exam difficulty (Z) causes both more studying (X) and higher stress (Y), creating a spurious association between X and Y.
key_insight: A common cause can create an association between X and Y even if X does not cause Y.
hidden_timestamp: Does exam difficulty directly influence both study time and stress level?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If exam difficulty does drive both study time and stress, the observed correlation is confounded and not causal.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If exam difficulty does not affect both, then the association might be more plausibly causal, but more evidence is needed.

wise_refusal: Without controlling for exam difficulty (the confounder), you cannot conclude that studying itself causes stress from correlation alone. This is a classic case of confounding.
gold_rationale: The observed association between study time and stress is likely due to confounding by exam difficulty, which increases both. The claim correctly identifies that correlation does not imply causation here, as the common cause (Z) explains the relationship.

scenario: A student notices that whenever they get an unusually high score on a short weekly quiz (X = “top 5% score”), their score on the next week’s quiz (Y) is typically lower. They conclude: “This doesn’t mean I ‘crashed’ after doing well—scores naturally regress toward my average.”
claim: Lower scores after an unusually high score can be explained by regression to the mean rather than a causal ‘crash’ caused by doing well.
label: NO

X.name: Unusually high weekly quiz score (extreme high)

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (noise creates extremes; subsequent measurement reverts toward average)
key_insight: Conditioning on extreme outcomes creates apparent reversals in subsequent outcomes even with no causal effect of X on Y.
hidden_timestamp: Are quiz scores noisy enough that extreme highs occur by chance?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If quiz scores are highly variable, a high score is likely due to chance and the next score will regress toward the mean.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If quiz scores are not variable and high scores always reflect a real change, then a drop would suggest a true reversal.

wise_refusal: A decline after a peak is expected under variability; you need a causal design to claim the peak caused the decline. This is a classic regression to the mean trap.
gold_rationale: Since X is defined as an extreme high score in a noisy process, Y will usually be closer to the student’s typical performance. The observed association does not imply that doing well causes a decline; it is explained by regression to the mean (W4).

scenario: A person tracks their mood daily. They notice that after their worst mood day of the month (X = “lowest mood score”), their mood the next day (Y) is usually better. They conclude: “Bad days often get followed by better days just because extremes don’t persist.”
claim: Mood improvement after the worst day can be explained by regression to the mean rather than the worst day causing a rebound.
label: NO

Z: Random day-to-day mood fluctuation / transient shocks

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (transient shocks create extreme low; next day likely closer to typical)
key_insight: Selecting the worst day guarantees it includes negative noise; the next day is likely less extreme.
hidden_timestamp: Is mood subject to transient shocks and measurement noise?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If mood is highly variable due to noise, the observed rebound is likely regression to the mean, not a causal effect.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If mood is perfectly stable and not subject to noise, then a rebound would suggest a true causal mechanism.

wise_refusal: A rebound after an extreme low is expected even without any ‘recovery mechanism’ caused by the low itself. This is a classic regression to the mean trap.
gold_rationale: Because the worst day is an extreme realization of a variable process, the next day’s mood will tend to be closer to baseline. This is classic regression to the mean: the apparent improvement does not imply that the low mood caused the rebound.

scenario: A salesperson tracks weekly revenue. After their best week of the year (X = “top week”), the next week’s revenue (Y) is typically lower. They say: “It’s probably regression to the mean; the best week was unusually good.”
claim: A drop in revenue after the best week can be explained by regression to the mean rather than the best week causing a subsequent slump.
label: NO

Z: Random variation in deal timing / pipeline noise

causal_structure: Random variation (Z) causes both an extreme high week (X) and influences the next week's revenue (Y); selecting on X induces regression to the mean in Y.
key_insight: Extreme weeks often include lucky timing; subsequent weeks revert.
hidden_timestamp: Is weekly revenue affected by random timing and lumpiness of deals?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If revenue is highly variable due to random timing, a drop after a peak is expected without any causal effect.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If revenue is not variable and the peak is due to a true change, a drop may indicate a causal effect.

wise_refusal: Regression to the mean explains the observed drop; the best week does not cause a slump, but rather reflects random variation.
gold_rationale: Because the 'best week' is selected as an extreme value in a noisy process, the next week's revenue is likely to be closer to the average due to regression to the mean. The observed association does not support a causal claim that the peak week causes a slump.

scenario: A person tracks daily step counts. After their highest-step day of the month (X = “max steps”), they usually walk fewer steps the next day (Y). They conclude: “That’s expected from variability; it doesn’t mean high-step days cause low-step days.”
claim: Lower steps after a highest-step day can be explained by regression to the mean rather than a causal ‘compensation’ caused by the high-step day.
label: NO

Z: Random variation in daily schedule/activity opportunities

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (schedule noise drives extremes; subsequent day reverts)
key_insight: Extremes are partly due to chance and context; the next day is likely closer to average.
hidden_timestamp: Are step counts driven by variable schedules (travel, errands) that create extreme days?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If step counts are driven by variable schedules, the observed pattern is likely due to regression to the mean.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If step counts are not driven by variable schedules, a causal compensation effect might be plausible.

wise_refusal: A post-peak decline is expected under noisy behavior; it doesn’t prove causal compensation without stronger evidence. This is a classic regression to the mean trap.
gold_rationale: Selecting the maximum step day ensures an extreme value influenced by variable context. The next day will likely be lower on average, consistent with regression to the mean. The observed association does not justify a causal claim of compensation.

scenario: A class notices that students who got the very highest score on one test (X = “top scorer”) usually get a lower score on the next test (Y). A student says: “That’s regression to the mean; being top once doesn’t cause worse performance next time.”
claim: Being the top scorer on one test causes lower performance on the next test.
label: NO

X.name: Being the top scorer on a test (extreme high)

Z: Random variation in test alignment/luck and measurement noise

causal_structure: Random variation (Z) affects both being a top scorer (X) and next test score (Y); selecting on X induces regression to the mean in Y.
key_insight: Extreme performance is partly due to luck; next scores tend to be less extreme due to regression to the mean.
hidden_timestamp: Do tests have enough random variation that even strong students can have unusually great days?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If there is substantial random variation, lower subsequent scores are expected due to regression to the mean.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If there is no random variation, being top scorer could indicate a true change in ability.

wise_refusal: We cannot conclude that being top scorer causes lower performance; the observed pattern is expected from regression to the mean due to random variation.
gold_rationale: Selecting top scorers conditions on an extreme realization of a noisy outcome. Next-test scores tend to be closer to their average, consistent with regression to the mean. The observed association does not imply that being top scorer causes a slump; it is a statistical artifact.

scenario: A basketball player observes that after their highest-scoring game of the season (X), the next game (Y) is usually less impressive. They say: “That’s expected; the highest game was unusually hot shooting.”
claim: Lower performance after the highest-scoring game can be explained by regression to the mean rather than the high-scoring game causing worse performance next time.
label: NO

Y.name: Points scored in the next game

Z: Random variation in shooting luck/opponent matchup

causal_structure: Random variation (Z) influences both the highest-scoring game (X) and the next game's performance (Y); selecting an extreme high (X) induces reversion toward the average in Y.
key_insight: Extreme performances often include favorable random factors; subsequent performances revert.
hidden_timestamp: Is game-to-game scoring noisy due to matchup and shooting variance?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If scoring is highly variable due to luck, then a drop after a high is expected from regression to the mean.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If scoring is not variable and the high game truly changes future performance, then a causal effect is possible.

wise_refusal: A drop after a personal best is expected under variance; it does not imply the best game caused a slump. This is a classic regression to the mean trap.
gold_rationale: Because X is selected as the highest-scoring game within a noisy scoring process, the next game’s points tend to be closer to average. Regression to the mean explains the association without requiring a causal effect of X on Y.

scenario: A person’s blood pressure reading at the pharmacy kiosk is unusually high one day (X = “highest reading this month”). The next day (Y) it is lower. They say: “That happens because single readings vary; the high one was an outlier.”
claim: A lower follow-up blood pressure reading after an unusually high reading can be explained by regression to the mean rather than the first reading causing a decrease.
label: NO

Z: Measurement noise or temporary factors (e.g., stress, caffeine) affecting the first reading

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (temporary factors and noise produce extreme reading; next is closer to baseline)
key_insight: Noisy physiological measurements often regress toward average on repeat testing.
hidden_timestamp: Are single BP readings influenced by transient factors like stress or caffeine?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If single readings are influenced by transient factors, the lower follow-up is likely regression to the mean.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If readings are not influenced by transient factors, a causal effect of the first reading on the second would be more plausible.

wise_refusal: This is a classic case of regression to the mean: an unusually high reading is likely to be followed by a more typical value due to random variation, not because the first reading caused the second to decrease.
gold_rationale: Because the initial reading can be influenced by transient factors and measurement variability, an unusually high value is likely to be followed by a less extreme value on retest. This is regression to the mean, not evidence that the first reading caused a decrease.

scenario: A retail store selects its ‘worst performing’ day in a month by lowest sales (X = “lowest sales day”). The next day’s sales (Y) are higher. The manager says: “That’s expected; the lowest day is an extreme, and sales will usually be higher afterward.”
claim: Higher sales after the lowest sales day can be explained by regression to the mean rather than the low-sales day causing a rebound.
label: NO

Z: Random variation in foot traffic, promotions, or weather

causal_structure: Random variation (Z) causes both the lowest sales day (X) and the next day's sales (Y); selecting an extreme low guarantees the next observation is likely higher due to noise.
key_insight: Selecting an extreme low guarantees the next value will likely be higher, even without a causal rebound.
hidden_timestamp: Are daily sales noisy due to varying traffic and external factors?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If sales are highly variable due to external factors, the next day's sales will likely be higher regardless of any causal effect.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If sales are perfectly stable with no noise, there would be no expected rebound after the lowest day.

wise_refusal: This pattern is expected from regression to the mean, not from a causal effect of the lowest sales day. Without an intervention or further evidence, we cannot claim causality.
gold_rationale: Because the worst day is selected as an extreme low in a variable process, the next day’s sales will usually be higher even without any causal ‘bounce back’ effect. This is regression to the mean: the apparent association is due to selection on an extreme, not a causal effect.

scenario: A school deploys an AI tool to flag cheating on online quizzes (X = “flagged by the tool”). The vendor claims the tool is 90% accurate. In one week, 30 students are flagged and administrators conclude: “Most flagged students must be cheaters.”
claim: If the tool is 90% accurate, then most students it flags are truly cheating.
label: NO

X.name: Being flagged by the AI cheating detector

Z: Base rate / prevalence of cheating in this class (rare vs common)

trap.subtype_name: Ignoring prevalence leads to low precision

causal_structure: Z → Y; Y → X (flag is an imperfect test for Y, and prevalence Z governs how informative X is)
key_insight: High overall accuracy does not imply most positive flags are true when the underlying event is rare.
hidden_timestamp: Is cheating rare (e.g., a few percent) or common in this population?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If cheating is rare, most flagged students may be innocent due to false positives.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If cheating is common, a flag is more likely to indicate true cheating, but you still need calibration and audits.

wise_refusal: You cannot conclude that most flagged students are cheaters without knowing the prevalence of cheating and the false positive/negative rates. This is a classic case of base rate neglect.
gold_rationale: The administrator's conclusion is unjustified because high accuracy does not guarantee that most flagged students are cheaters, especially if cheating is rare. When the base rate of cheating is low, even a highly accurate detector can produce many false positives, leading to most flagged students being innocent. The prevalence of cheating (Z) is essential to interpret the meaning of a positive flag (X) for actual cheating (Y).

scenario: A neighborhood installs smart smoke alarms that send phone notifications (X = “alarm notification received”). One month later, residents complain that ‘alarms are going off all the time,’ and conclude: “There must be lots of house fires in our neighborhood.”
claim: Frequent smoke-alarm notifications imply that house fires are common in the neighborhood.
label: NO

Z: Nuisance triggers (cooking smoke/steam) that also generate alarms

trap.subtype_name: Alert frequency can be high even when the true event is rare

causal_structure: Y → X and Z → X; base rate of Y is low so X frequency does not equal Y frequency
key_insight: When the true event is rare and there are nuisance triggers, many alerts can be false alarms.
hidden_timestamp: Are most notifications caused by nuisance triggers rather than confirmed fires?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If most notifications are caused by nuisance triggers, frequent alarms do not imply frequent fires.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If nearly all notifications are caused by real fires, then frequent alarms would indicate frequent fires.

wise_refusal: I cannot infer that house fires are common from frequent alarm notifications without knowing the false-alarm rate; this is a classic case of base rate neglect.
gold_rationale: Frequent alerts can be driven by nuisance triggers even if real fires are rare, so inferring ‘many fires’ from notifications is invalid. The base rate of actual fires is likely low, and nuisance triggers can cause many false alarms, leading to an overestimation of fire frequency if base rates are ignored.

scenario: After three days in a row of rainy weather, Maya says: “We’re due for sunshine tomorrow—rain can’t keep happening.”
claim: After several rainy days, the next day is more likely to be sunny because weather ‘balances out.’
label: NO

X.name: Having multiple rainy days in a row

Z: Whether the weather process is independent vs. driven by persistent systems

trap.subtype_name: Assuming outcomes must ‘even out’ without evidence

causal_structure: Past rain does not force a reversal; if anything, persistence can make streaks more likely.
key_insight: A streak does not imply the opposite outcome is now more likely; ‘due’ reasoning is not justified.
hidden_timestamp: Do local weather patterns often persist across days rather than reversing?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If weather patterns persist, then rain is likely to continue.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If weather is truly independent day-to-day, past rain does not affect tomorrow's chance of sun.

wise_refusal: We cannot conclude that sun is more likely after a streak of rain without evidence of negative dependence; this is a regression to the mean/gambler’s fallacy trap.
gold_rationale: The claim commits the gambler’s fallacy by assuming weather must 'balance out' after a streak, but without evidence of negative dependence, past rain does not make sun more likely. In fact, weather patterns often persist, so the claim is not causally justified.

scenario: Leo flips a fair coin and gets heads five times in a row. Leo says: “Tails is more likely next because the outcomes should even out.”
claim: After five heads in a row, tails is more likely on the next flip.
label: NO

X.name: A streak of heads in previous flips

trap.subtype_name: Assuming negative dependence in independent trials

causal_structure: If flips are independent, P(Y|X)=P(Y)=0.5
key_insight: Independent events do not ‘compensate’ for past outcomes.
hidden_timestamp: Is the coin fair and are flips independent (no switching coins / changing technique)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the coin is fair and flips are independent, the probability of tails remains 0.5.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the coin or flipping conditions changed, the probability could differ from 0.5.

wise_refusal: Streaks happen under randomness; unless something changed, the next flip remains 50/50. This is a classic regression to the mean trap.
gold_rationale: For a fair coin, the probability of tails on the next flip remains 0.5 regardless of prior streaks. The claim incorrectly assumes that past outcomes influence future independent events, which is a regression to the mean (Gambler’s Fallacy) trap.

scenario: Tara starts wearing a ‘lucky’ bracelet (X). Over the next month, she vividly recalls a few times she wore it and her team won. She tells friends: “This bracelet makes us win.”
claim: Wearing the lucky bracelet causes Tara’s team to win more often.
label: NO

Y.name: Perceived/remembered wins while wearing the bracelet

causal_structure: Z (confirmation bias/selective recall) influences both X (wearing the bracelet) and Y (perceived wins), creating a spurious association.
key_insight: Selective recall and attention can create an illusory association without a causal mechanism.
hidden_timestamp: Does Tara systematically track all games (including losses while wearing the bracelet), or only recall notable wins?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If Tara only recalls notable wins, the association is likely spurious due to selective recall.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If Tara tracks all outcomes systematically, we could better assess any real effect.

wise_refusal: We cannot conclude causality because Tara's evidence is based on selective recall, a form of selection bias.
gold_rationale: The observed association is explained by selection bias: Tara remembers wins while wearing the bracelet and ignores losses, so the evidence does not support a causal effect of the bracelet.

scenario: A couple reads horoscopes (X = “same zodiac element”) and notices that among their friends, a few couples with the same element seem happier. They conclude: “Zodiac compatibility causes better relationships.”
claim: Sharing a zodiac element causes couples to have happier relationships.
label: NO

Z: Belief in astrology shaping attention and interpretation of anecdotes

trap.subtype_name: Belief drives which examples are noticed

causal_structure: Belief in astrology (Z) influences both noticing couples with the same zodiac element (X) and interpreting their happiness (Y), creating a spurious association.
key_insight: Anecdotes filtered through beliefs create spurious patterns without establishing causality.
hidden_timestamp: Are they relying on selective anecdotes rather than representative data?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the couples were selected randomly and happiness was measured objectively, the association might be meaningful.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If couples were noticed because of prior belief in astrology, the association is likely spurious.

wise_refusal: This is a classic case of confounding: belief in astrology shapes both which couples are noticed and how their happiness is interpreted, so we cannot infer causality from these anecdotes.
gold_rationale: The claim is invalid because the observed association is confounded by belief in astrology, which affects both the exposure (noticing couples with the same zodiac element) and the outcome (perceived happiness). Without representative data and objective measurement, the causal claim is not justified.

scenario: A group of adults is randomly assigned to either drink a cup of green tea every morning or not for six months. At the end of the study, those who drank green tea daily have lower average blood pressure compared to those who did not.
claim: Drinking green tea daily causes lower blood pressure in adults.
label: YES
causal_structure: Random assignment of green tea consumption ensures that confounders like diet and exercise are balanced between groups, allowing for a direct estimate of the causal effect of green tea on blood pressure.
key_insight: Randomized controlled trials provide strong evidence for causality by balancing confounders.
hidden_timestamp: Was the assignment to drink green tea truly random for all participants?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If assignment was truly random, the observed association supports a causal effect.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If assignment was not random, confounding could explain the association.

wise_refusal: This is a valid causal claim because the randomized controlled trial design eliminates confounding, supporting the conclusion that daily green tea consumption lowers blood pressure.
gold_rationale: Because participants were randomly assigned to drink green tea or not, confounders such as diet and exercise habits (Z) are likely balanced between groups. This means the observed difference in blood pressure (Y) can be attributed to green tea consumption (X), supporting the causal claim.

scenario: A city unexpectedly banned cars from the downtown area for one month due to a sudden environmental regulation, while a similar nearby city did not implement any such ban. Researchers compared air quality in both cities during this period.
claim: Banning cars from downtown causes improved air quality.
label: YES
causal_structure: An exogenous shock (car ban) in one city but not the other allows comparison of air quality outcomes, controlling for confounders by using a natural experiment design.
key_insight: Exogenous policy changes can reveal causal effects when compared to a similar untreated group.
hidden_timestamp: Was there any other major event affecting air quality in either city during the ban period?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If no other major events occurred, the car ban likely caused the improvement in air quality.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If another event (e.g., factory shutdown) occurred, the observed improvement may not be due to the car ban alone.

wise_refusal: This is a strong natural experiment: the exogenous car ban and comparison with a similar city support a causal interpretation, as confounding is minimized.
gold_rationale: The scenario describes a natural experiment (S2), where the car ban was imposed exogenously in one city but not the other, allowing for a clear comparison. By comparing air quality during the same period and controlling for confounders like weather and industrial emissions (Z), the evidence supports the claim that banning cars causes improved air quality. The identification strategy leverages the exogenous shock and a control group, justifying the causal claim.

scenario: A city allocates parking permits to residents using a lottery system due to limited availability. Researchers compare the car ownership rates of those who won the lottery to those who did not.
claim: Winning a parking permit lottery causes an increase in car ownership.
label: YES
causal_structure: Random assignment via lottery ensures that, on average, confounders like income and transit access are balanced between winners and non-winners, so differences in car ownership can be attributed to winning the permit.
key_insight: Lottery-based assignment provides strong evidence for causality by balancing confounders.
hidden_timestamp: Were the lottery assignments truly random and not manipulated or stratified by neighborhood?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the lottery was truly random, the causal claim is justified.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the lottery was not random, confounding could bias the results.

wise_refusal: The use of a lottery for parking permits creates quasi-random assignment, which balances both observed and unobserved confounders, supporting a valid causal inference from winning the lottery to increased car ownership.
gold_rationale: Because parking permits were allocated by lottery (S3), assignment to treatment (winning) is as good as random, so pre-existing differences (Z: income, transit access) should not bias the comparison. Therefore, the observed association between winning and car ownership can be interpreted causally.

scenario: A group of people agrees to stop using their smartphones for one week while continuing all other routines as usual. Researchers observe that, compared to a similar group who keeps using smartphones, the group without smartphones reports significantly lower stress levels at the end of the week.
claim: Not using smartphones causes lower stress levels.
label: YES
causal_structure: Ablation: X (not using smartphones) is removed while holding other factors constant, and Y (stress levels) is measured, minimizing confounding.
key_insight: Controlled ablation isolates the effect of smartphone use on stress.
hidden_timestamp: Did participants change any other major habits besides smartphone usage during the week?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If no other habits changed, the reduction in stress can be attributed to not using smartphones.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If other habits changed, the observed effect may be due to those changes, not just smartphone use.

wise_refusal: This is a strong causal design: by removing smartphone use while keeping other routines constant, the evidence supports that not using smartphones causes lower stress levels.
gold_rationale: The scenario describes a controlled ablation (S4), where the only manipulated variable is smartphone usage (X), and all other routines are held constant. The outcome (Y) is stress level. Potential confounders like workload and social support (Z) are controlled by design. The observed difference in stress between groups can be causally attributed to not using smartphones, as the identification strategy isolates X's effect on Y.

scenario: A large study tracked people who started drinking green tea daily and compared them to those who did not. Researchers found that those who drank green tea had lower rates of developing high blood pressure, and the effect increased with the number of cups consumed per day.
claim: Drinking green tea daily reduces the risk of developing high blood pressure.
label: YES
causal_structure: The study observes a dose-response relationship between green tea consumption (X) and reduced risk of high blood pressure (Y), with plausible biological mechanisms (antioxidants in green tea affecting blood vessel function) and adjustment for major confounders (Z).
key_insight: A clear dose-response and plausible mechanism strongly support a causal link.
hidden_timestamp: Did the researchers control for all major lifestyle confounders such as exercise and diet?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If confounders were controlled, the association is likely causal.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If confounders were not controlled, the association may be spurious.

wise_refusal: The evidence is strong because the dose-response gradient and plausible mechanism, combined with adjustment for confounders, support a causal interpretation.
gold_rationale: The study demonstrates that increased green tea consumption (X) is associated with lower incidence of high blood pressure (Y) in a dose-dependent manner, and the biological mechanism (antioxidant effects) is well-established. Major confounders (Z: dietary habits, physical activity) were considered, strengthening the causal inference. This fits S5: Mechanism + Dose Response, justifying the claim.

scenario: A city implements a congestion charge policy for vehicles entering downtown, but only on days when air pollution exceeds a certain threshold. Researchers use the number of days with high wind (which disperses pollution but does not affect traffic demand) as an instrumental variable to study the effect of the congestion charge on average commute times.
claim: Implementing a congestion charge reduces average commute times.
label: YES
causal_structure: High wind is used as an instrumental variable: it affects the likelihood of the congestion charge being implemented (by lowering pollution) but is plausibly independent of baseline traffic demand and directly affects commute time only through the policy.
key_insight: A valid instrumental variable can reveal causal effects even when direct randomization is not possible.
hidden_timestamp: Does high wind affect commute times through any channel other than triggering the congestion charge?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If high wind only affects commute times via the congestion charge, the IV estimate is valid and supports causality.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If high wind directly affects commute times (e.g., by making driving more difficult), the IV is invalid and causality is not established.

wise_refusal: The use of high wind as an instrumental variable is justified here because it plausibly satisfies the exclusion restriction: it only affects commute times through its impact on the likelihood of the congestion charge being implemented, not directly. This supports a valid causal inference.
gold_rationale: The scenario employs an instrumental variable (high wind) that influences the implementation of the congestion charge (X) but is not directly related to average commute times (Y) except through X. Weather conditions and baseline traffic demand (Z) are accounted for. The identification strategy hinges on the assumption that high wind does not independently affect commute times. If this holds, the observed association can be interpreted causally, satisfying the requirements for a valid IV (S6).

scenario: A city implemented a new bike lane policy in 2020. Researchers compared the change in daily bike commuting rates before and after 2020 in this city and in a similar nearby city that did not implement the policy. Both cities had similar trends in bike commuting before 2020.
claim: Implementing the new bike lane policy increased daily bike commuting rates.
label: YES
causal_structure: Difference-in-differences: compare pre- and post-policy changes in the treated city to changes in a control city with parallel pre-trends.
key_insight: Parallel trends in control and treatment cities allow valid causal inference from the policy change.
hidden_timestamp: Did both cities have similar trends in bike commuting rates before 2020?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If both cities had parallel pre-trends, the difference-in-differences estimate is valid.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If pre-trends diverged, the estimate may be biased and causality is not established.

wise_refusal: The evidence supports causality because the difference-in-differences design with parallel pre-trends controls for confounders that are constant over time between the cities.
gold_rationale: The scenario uses a difference-in-differences approach (S7), comparing changes in daily bike commuting rates before and after the policy in both the treated and control cities. Since the cities had similar pre-policy trends, this design controls for confounders like weather and public transportation changes that affect both cities equally, supporting the causal claim that the bike lane policy increased commuting rates.

scenario: A city implemented a new policy where households with electricity bills just above a certain threshold received a free energy audit, while those just below did not. Researchers compared energy usage reductions for households just above and just below the threshold.
claim: Receiving a free energy audit causes households to reduce their energy usage.
label: YES
causal_structure: Households are assigned to treatment (energy audit) based on a strict cutoff in electricity bills, allowing for a local comparison of similar households just above and below the threshold (regression discontinuity design).
key_insight: A regression discontinuity at a policy cutoff can reveal causal effects when assignment is as-good-as-random near the threshold.
hidden_timestamp: Were there any other policy changes or incentives at the cutoff besides the energy audit?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If no other changes occurred at the cutoff, the reduction in energy usage can be causally attributed to the energy audit.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If other incentives were also introduced at the cutoff, the observed effect may not be solely due to the energy audit.

wise_refusal: This case uses a regression discontinuity design, where households just above and below the threshold are likely comparable except for receiving the audit. This supports a valid causal inference from the observed association.
gold_rationale: The regression discontinuity design leverages a sharp cutoff in policy assignment, ensuring that households near the threshold are similar in all respects except for receiving the energy audit (X). This allows for a credible estimate of the causal effect of X on Y (energy usage reduction), controlling for potential confounders like household income and size (Z). The evidence type (S8) is strong, justifying the causal claim.

scenario: A survey finds that people who drink herbal tea every evening report better sleep quality than those who do not. The survey does not collect information about participants' overall health or stress levels.
claim: Drinking herbal tea every evening causes better sleep quality.
label: AMBIGUOUS
causal_structure: X may influence Y, but Z (overall health, stress levels) could confound the association; the direction and strength of causality are unclear without more information.
key_insight: Without knowing if healthier or less stressed people are more likely to drink herbal tea, causality cannot be established.
hidden_timestamp: Do people who drink herbal tea differ systematically in health or stress from those who do not?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If herbal tea drinkers are generally healthier or less stressed, the association may be due to these confounders, not the tea itself.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If herbal tea drinkers are otherwise similar to non-drinkers in health and stress, the association may reflect a causal effect.

wise_refusal: Causal inference is not justified here because key confounders like overall health and stress levels are unmeasured; the relationship is ambiguous.
gold_rationale: The observed association between herbal tea drinking and better sleep quality could be explained by unmeasured confounders such as overall health or stress levels (Z). Without information on these variables, we cannot determine if X truly causes Y or if the association is spurious. Thus, the causal claim is ambiguous.

scenario: A survey finds that people who regularly drink herbal tea report lower stress levels compared to those who do not. The survey does not include information about participants' overall health habits or life circumstances.
claim: Drinking herbal tea causes lower stress levels.
label: AMBIGUOUS
causal_structure: X (herbal tea) may affect Y (stress), but Z (health habits, life circumstances) could confound the association; the direction and strength of causality are unclear without more information.
key_insight: Association alone is not enough to establish causality when key confounders are unmeasured.
hidden_timestamp: Did the survey control for participants' general health habits or major life stressors?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the survey controlled for these confounders, the association might suggest a causal link.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the survey did not control for these confounders, the association could be spurious.

wise_refusal: A causal conclusion cannot be drawn because the association may be confounded by unmeasured health habits or life circumstances.
gold_rationale: The observed association between herbal tea consumption (X) and lower stress levels (Y) could be due to other factors (Z) such as healthier lifestyles or less stressful environments among tea drinkers. Without controlling for these confounders, we cannot determine if X truly causes Y, making the claim ambiguous.

scenario: A survey of office workers found that those who drank coffee during their morning break tended to report feeling more alert in the following hour. The survey included responses from employees across different departments and age groups, but did not control for other factors.
claim: Among office workers, drinking coffee during the morning break is associated with feeling more alert in the following hour.

Y.name: feeling more alert in the following hour

wise_refusal: The claim is supported because the survey found that coffee drinkers reported feeling more alert after their morning break. This is an association, not a causal statement, and matches the evidence provided.
label: YES
gold_rationale: The scenario describes an observed association between drinking coffee and feeling more alert among office workers. At Pearl level L1, only correlational evidence is required, and the survey results directly support the claim as stated. No causal or statistical assumptions are violated, and no trap applies.

scenario: A survey of office workers found that those who regularly take short breaks during the workday report feeling less fatigued by the end of the day compared to those who do not take breaks. The survey included responses from employees across several departments in the same company.
claim: Among office workers, taking regular short breaks during the workday is associated with feeling less fatigued by the end of the day.

Y.name: feeling less fatigued by the end of the day

wise_refusal: The claim is supported because the scenario describes a clear association between taking regular breaks and feeling less fatigued, based on survey responses. No further information is needed to accept the claim as stated.
label: YES
gold_rationale: The scenario provides observational data showing an association between taking regular short breaks and reporting less fatigue among office workers. The claim is stated in correlational terms and is directly supported by the data described. No causal or statistical assumption is violated at this level of reasoning.

scenario: A study examines the relationship between daily coffee consumption and reported productivity, but only includes employees who received 'Employee of the Month' awards. The researchers find that among these selected high performers, those who drink more coffee tend to report higher productivity scores.
claim: Among office workers, drinking more coffee is associated with higher productivity.
wise_refusal: This is a classic selection bias: by only looking at award winners, the apparent link between coffee and productivity may not reflect the true association for all employees.
label: NO
gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The analysis only includes employees who have already been recognized for high productivity, meaning the sample is selected based on the outcome variable (productivity). Correct Reasoning. This selection distorts the observed association between coffee consumption and productivity, as the link may not exist in the broader population. Wise Refusal. The observed association could be entirely due to sampling only high performers; the relationship may not hold for typical workers.

scenario: A company analyzes the relationship between employees who frequently work overtime (X) and those who report high job satisfaction (Y), but only includes employees who volunteered for a recent company retreat (Z) in the analysis. Participation in the retreat was optional and tended to attract both highly satisfied employees and those who work overtime to meet project deadlines.
claim: Among employees who attended the company retreat, those who work overtime are more likely to report high job satisfaction.
wise_refusal: This could be selection bias: since retreat participation depends on both overtime and satisfaction, the observed link in this subset may be misleading and cannot be generalized.
label: NO
gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. By restricting the analysis to only those who participated in the retreat, which is influenced by both working overtime and job satisfaction, a spurious association between overtime and satisfaction may be induced. Correct Reasoning. Conditioning on retreat participation (a collider) can create or distort the observed relationship between overtime and satisfaction, even if no association exists in the general employee population.

scenario: A survey was conducted among people who use public transportation, asking if they listen to music during their commute. However, the survey does not specify whether it included only morning commuters, evening commuters, or both. The results show that many respondents reported feeling less stressed during their commute when they listened to music.
claim: Listening to music during a commute is associated with lower stress levels among public transportation users.
wise_refusal: We can't be certain about the association because the survey's sampling details are missing. Without knowing which commuters were included, the results may not apply to all public transportation users.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: The scenario suggests a possible association between listening to music and lower stress levels, but it is unclear whether the survey included all relevant groups (morning and/or evening commuters). Without knowing the sampling frame, we cannot be sure the association holds for all public transportation users. The missing information makes it impossible to confidently evaluate the claim.

scenario: A survey was conducted among office workers about their coffee consumption and self-reported alertness during the workday. However, the survey does not specify whether the alertness ratings were collected before or after coffee consumption, nor does it indicate if participants consumed coffee on the day of the survey.
claim: Among office workers, drinking coffee is associated with higher alertness during the workday.
wise_refusal: We cannot be sure whether coffee drinking is associated with higher alertness because the survey does not clarify when the alertness was measured or if coffee was consumed that day. More details are needed to evaluate the claim.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: The scenario lacks critical information about the timing of coffee consumption relative to the alertness ratings and whether coffee was actually consumed on the day of the survey. Without this information, it is impossible to determine if there is an association between coffee drinking and alertness among the surveyed office workers.

scenario: A company analyzes employees who attend both the annual innovation workshop and receive high performance reviews. They notice that those who work overtime are more likely to be in this group and also tend to receive more promotions. The analysis only includes employees who attended the workshop and got high reviews.
claim: Among employees who attend the innovation workshop and receive high reviews, working overtime is associated with receiving more promotions.

Z.name: attendance at innovation workshop and high performance review

wise_refusal: Conditioning on who is included (workshop attendees with high reviews) can artificially create an association between overtime and promotions. The observed link may not reflect the true relationship in the broader group.
label: NO
gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. By restricting the analysis to employees who both attend the workshop and receive high reviews (a common effect of overtime and promotions), the study conditions on a collider. Correct Reasoning. This selection can induce a spurious association between working overtime and receiving more promotions, even if no true association exists in the full employee population. Wise Refusal. "This could be selection bias: conditioning on workshop attendance and high reviews may create a misleading link between overtime and promotions."

scenario: A survey of office workers found that those who drink coffee in the morning are more likely to report feeling alert during the first few hours of work. The survey did not control for other factors, but the association between morning coffee drinking and feeling alert was observed across the group.
claim: Among office workers, drinking coffee in the morning is associated with feeling alert during the first few hours of work.

Y.name: feeling alert during the first few hours of work

wise_refusal: The claim is supported because the scenario describes a clear association between morning coffee drinking and feeling alert, which is all that is required at this level.
label: YES
gold_rationale: The scenario provides observational data showing an association between morning coffee drinking and feeling alert among office workers. At Pearl level L1, only the presence of an association is required, and the scenario directly supports the claim as stated. No causal or statistical assumption is violated.

scenario: A survey of office workers found that those who drank coffee during the workday were more likely to report feeling alert in the afternoon compared to those who did not drink coffee. The survey did not control for other factors such as sleep quality or workload.
claim: Among office workers, drinking coffee during the workday is associated with feeling alert in the afternoon.
wise_refusal: The claim is supported because the scenario directly reports an association between drinking coffee and feeling alert in the afternoon. No further information is needed to establish this association at the observational level.
label: YES
gold_rationale: The scenario provides observational data indicating an association between coffee consumption and afternoon alertness among office workers. At the L1 (Association) level, it is sufficient to state that drinking coffee is associated with feeling alert, regardless of possible confounders. The claim is supported as stated by the scenario.

scenario: A survey is conducted among employees who have recently received a promotion at work, asking about their job satisfaction levels. The analysis finds that those who were promoted after working overtime report higher satisfaction than those promoted without overtime. The survey only includes employees who received a promotion in the past year.
claim: Among employees, working overtime is associated with higher job satisfaction.
wise_refusal: Because the survey only includes promoted employees, the apparent link between overtime and satisfaction may be misleading. Selection on promotion status can distort the true relationship.
label: NO
gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The sample only includes employees who received a recent promotion, conditioning on an outcome-related variable. Correct Reasoning. By restricting analysis to promoted employees, we select a group where both overtime and satisfaction may be linked to promotion, distorting the association between overtime and satisfaction for all employees. Wise Refusal. "This could be selection bias: since only promoted employees are surveyed, the observed link between overtime and satisfaction may not reflect the true association for all employees."

scenario: A group of coworkers noticed that some people who bring homemade lunches to work seem to have more energy in the afternoons. However, there is no information about what types of food are included in these homemade lunches or whether other factors, such as sleep or workload, were considered.
claim: Bringing a homemade lunch to work is associated with having more afternoon energy.

X.name: bringing a homemade lunch to work

wise_refusal: We cannot be sure about the association because important details about the lunches and other possible influences on energy are missing. More information is needed to evaluate the claim.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: The scenario suggests a possible association between bringing homemade lunches and afternoon energy, but lacks critical information about what is in the lunches, as well as other relevant factors like sleep or workload. Without these details, it is not possible to determine whether the observed association is valid or if other explanations exist.

scenario: A survey was conducted among office workers to see if those who drink coffee at work tend to report higher levels of alertness during the afternoon. The survey collected responses about coffee consumption and self-reported alertness, but did not ask about other habits or health conditions. The results showed that coffee drinkers reported higher afternoon alertness than non-coffee drinkers.
claim: Among office workers, drinking coffee at work is associated with higher afternoon alertness.
wise_refusal: The claim is supported by the observed association in the survey. Based on the data, office workers who drink coffee tend to report higher afternoon alertness.
label: YES
gold_rationale: The scenario provides observational data showing a positive association between coffee consumption and afternoon alertness among office workers. Since the claim is about association and does not imply causation, the evidence directly supports it at the L1 (Association) level. No causal or statistical assumption is violated, and no trap applies.

scenario: A survey is conducted among people who have recently quit their jobs to assess their levels of job satisfaction before leaving. The sample only includes individuals who have voluntarily resigned within the last month. Researchers find that most respondents report low job satisfaction prior to quitting.
claim: Among all employees, low job satisfaction is strongly associated with quitting a job.
wise_refusal: This could be selection bias: surveying only those who quit means the observed association may not reflect the true relationship among all employees.
label: NO
gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The survey only includes people who have already quit, so the sample is conditioned on the outcome (quitting). Correct Reasoning. This selection distorts the observed association between job satisfaction and quitting, as it excludes those who stayed despite low satisfaction or quit for other reasons. Wise Refusal. "This is selection bias: by only surveying quitters, the link between low satisfaction and quitting is exaggerated and cannot be generalized to all employees."

scenario: A survey was conducted among employees at an office to find out how many drink coffee regularly. The results showed that a majority reported drinking coffee at least once a day. However, the survey did not ask about whether employees work in different departments or have varying work schedules.
claim: There is an association between being an office employee and drinking coffee regularly.
wise_refusal: It's unclear whether the association applies to all office employees since the survey may have missed important differences between groups. More information about who was surveyed is needed to confirm the claim.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: The scenario suggests that many office employees drink coffee regularly, but it does not specify whether all types of employees or work schedules were included. Without knowing if the survey covered all relevant groups or if there were differences based on department or schedule, we cannot be certain about the association for all office employees.

scenario: A survey is conducted among employees who have recently received promotions at a large company. The survey finds that those who attended leadership workshops are more likely to report high job satisfaction than those who did not. However, only employees who were promoted were invited to participate in the survey.
claim: Attending leadership workshops is associated with higher job satisfaction among employees.
wise_refusal: Since the survey only includes promoted employees, the apparent link between workshops and satisfaction could be misleading. The results may not apply to all employees, especially those not promoted.
label: NO
gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The sample only includes employees who were promoted, which is likely related to both attending workshops and job satisfaction. Correct Reasoning. By conditioning on promotion status, the observed association between workshop attendance and job satisfaction may be distorted, as those not promoted (and possibly less satisfied) are excluded. Wise Refusal. "This could be selection bias: since only promoted employees are surveyed, the link between workshops and satisfaction may not reflect the true association for all employees."

scenario: A group of office workers were surveyed about their coffee drinking habits and their reported alertness levels during the workday. The results show that those who drink coffee in the morning tend to report feeling more alert throughout the day compared to those who do not drink coffee.
claim: Morning coffee drinking is associated with higher reported alertness among office workers.
wise_refusal: The claim holds as stated because the scenario provides direct observational evidence of an association between morning coffee drinking and higher alertness among office workers.
label: YES
gold_rationale: The scenario describes an observed association between morning coffee drinking and higher reported alertness among office workers. Since the claim is about association and the data directly supports this, the claim is valid at the L1 (Association) level. No causal or statistical assumptions are violated.

scenario: A survey was conducted among office workers about their lunch habits. Some reported eating salads for lunch, while others did not specify what they ate. The survey results include the number of people who reported feeling energetic in the afternoon, but it is unclear which individuals ate salads and which did not.
claim: Eating salads for lunch is associated with feeling more energetic in the afternoon among office workers.
wise_refusal: We can't tell if eating salads is linked to feeling energetic because the survey doesn't specify which people ate salads and which felt energetic. More detailed information is needed to evaluate this claim.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: The scenario does not provide enough information to determine whether those who ate salads are the same individuals who felt energetic in the afternoon. Without clear data linking lunch choices to energy levels, the association cannot be verified. Critical details about the overlap between salad eaters and energetic respondents are missing.

scenario: A survey of employees who recently received promotions shows that they tend to report working longer hours than those who did not get promoted. The data only includes responses from employees after the promotion decisions were announced.
claim: Working longer hours is associated with a higher chance of being promoted.
wise_refusal: Be careful: promoted employees might work longer hours because of their new roles, not the other way around. The association could be driven by the outcome influencing the exposure.
label: NO
gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. The dataset only includes employees after promotion decisions, so those who were promoted may have started working longer hours because of their new responsibilities. Correct Reasoning. The observed association may reflect that the outcome (promotion) led to increased working hours, not that longer hours caused promotion. This is a classic case of reverse causality due to outcome-driven selection.

scenario: A company analyzes employee data and finds that, overall, employees who work remotely have lower average performance scores than those who work in the office. However, when the data is split by department, remote workers in each department actually have higher performance scores than their in-office peers. The company is considering discouraging remote work based on the overall numbers.
claim: Employees who work remotely tend to have lower performance scores than those who work in the office.
wise_refusal: This is a classic case of Simpson's paradox: the overall numbers don't reflect the true relationship within each department. Aggregating across departments can hide or even reverse the real patterns.
label: NO
gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. Simpson's paradox is present: the overall association between remote work and lower performance reverses when the data is stratified by department. Correct Reasoning. The aggregated data masks the true relationship within each department, likely due to differences in department size or composition. Wise Refusal. The claim is invalid because the overall trend is misleading; the association reverses when accounting for department.

scenario: A survey was conducted among employees at a large company to see how many people bring lunch from home. The results showed that 60% of respondents reported bringing lunch from home at least three times a week. However, the survey does not specify whether all departments or work shifts were included.
claim: Bringing lunch from home at least three times a week is common among employees at this company.

X.name: bringing lunch from home at least three times a week

wise_refusal: Because the survey details are incomplete, we can't be sure that bringing lunch from home is common across all employees. More information about who was surveyed would be needed to confirm the claim.
label: AMBIGUOUS
gold_rationale: The scenario provides a percentage based on survey responses, but it is unclear if the survey sample represents all employees, departments, or work shifts. Without knowing the sampling method, we cannot be certain that the claim applies to the entire company. This missing information makes it impossible to definitively evaluate the claim.

scenario: A company reviews employee satisfaction scores and finds that, overall, remote workers report lower satisfaction than in-office workers. However, when the data is split by department, remote workers in each department consistently report higher satisfaction than their in-office colleagues. The overall trend reverses within departmental subgroups.
claim: Remote work is associated with lower employee satisfaction.
wise_refusal: This is a case of Simpson's paradox: the overall trend hides the true relationship within subgroups. Always check subgroup patterns before drawing conclusions from aggregated data.
label: NO
gold_rationale: The Statistical Structure. When the data is aggregated across all departments, remote workers appear less satisfied, but within each department, the opposite is true: remote workers are more satisfied. Correct Reasoning. This is a classic example of Simpson's paradox, where the overall association is reversed within subgroups due to imbalanced group composition. The claim is invalid because it ignores the departmental breakdown, misleadingly suggesting a negative association.

At the L1 (Association) level, this is sufficient to support the claim as stated, since no causal or statistical assumption is violated. The claim does not imply causation, only association, which matches the data provided.

scenario: A student scores 95% on their first calculus exam after cramming all night. They continue the same study method but score 78% on the second exam and 75% on the third. They conclude their study technique stopped working and switch to a different approach.
claim: The cramming study method stopped working effectively
label: NO
causal_structure: Initial extreme performance due to unsustainable effort; subsequent scores reflect true sustainable performance level.
key_insight: First exam score was an outlier driven by unsustainable cramming intensity.
hidden_timestamp: Did the student's energy and mental sharpness decline after the first exam?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If cramming intensity remained constant, scores decline due to accumulated fatigue.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the student switched to sustainable study methods earlier, more consistent performance is likely.

wise_refusal: This is regression to the mean. The 95% first exam was an outlier driven by unsustainable cramming intensity. The declining scores represent the true sustainable rate under this exhausting method. Switching techniques restarts the initial effort cycle but doesn't address the underlying unsustainability.
gold_rationale: The student's conclusion commits the regression to mean trap. The first exam's 95% score was an extreme value achieved through unsustainable all-night cramming. This intense effort depleted the student's mental energy and cognitive resources, making it impossible to maintain that performance level. The subsequent scores (78%, 75%) represent the true performance level achievable with this exhausting study method, not evidence that the technique 'stopped working.'

scenario: A new employee completes 20 tasks in their first week, impressing their manager. In week two, they complete 12 tasks, and week three brings 10 tasks. The manager concludes the employee's motivation has declined and considers performance improvement measures.

causal_structure: Initial extreme performance due to unsustainable new-hire effort; subsequent output reflects true sustainable capacity.

wise_refusal: This is regression to the mean. The 20-task first week was an outlier driven by unsustainable new-hire overwork to impress. The subsequent weeks show the employee's true sustainable productivity rate. Performance improvement measures would be misguided since this represents normal capacity, not declined motivation.
gold_rationale: The manager's conclusion commits the regression to mean trap. The employee's first week of 20 tasks was an extreme value achieved through unsustainable overwork and new-hire enthusiasm to make a good impression. This pace depleted the employee's energy and was impossible to maintain. The subsequent task counts (12, 10) represent the employee's true sustainable productivity capacity under normal working conditions, not evidence of declining motivation.

scenario: A startup's app gains 50,000 downloads in its first week after a viral social media post. The following week sees 8,000 downloads, and week three brings 5,000. The founders conclude their marketing strategy stopped working and pivot to a new approach.
