wise_refusal: This is regression to the mean. The 50,000 first-week downloads were an outlier driven by viral novelty and early adopter interest. The subsequent weeks show the true sustainable download rate under normal marketing conditions. Pivoting strategies will restart the novelty cycle but won't change the underlying organic reach.
gold_rationale: The founders' conclusion commits the regression to mean trap. The first week's 50,000 downloads were an extreme value achieved through a viral social media post that attracted novelty-seeking early adopters. This viral effect is inherently unsustainable as the pool of interested early adopters gets exhausted and novelty fades. The subsequent download rates (8,000, 5,000) represent the true sustainable reach of their marketing under normal conditions, not evidence that the strategy stopped working.

scenario: A teacher notices that students who receive intensive tutoring after failing an exam show greater improvement than those receiving standard help. The teacher mandates intensive tutoring for all struggling students, but overall performance drops.
claim: Intensive tutoring is more effective than standard help for all struggling students
label: NO
causal_structure: Intensive tutoring was selectively applied to worst performers (extreme low); these naturally regress toward mean. Applied universally, it reduces independent study time.
key_insight: Greatest improvement occurs from lowest baseline; intensive tutoring may harm students who need independent study time.
hidden_timestamp: Was intensive tutoring only given to students with the lowest initial performance, or to all struggling students regardless of baseline?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If intensive tutoring is applied only to failing students, apparent success is likely due to regression to the mean.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If intensive tutoring is applied to all struggling students, overall performance may drop due to reduced independent study time.

wise_refusal: This is a case of regression to the mean combined with intervention at extremes. The apparent success of intensive tutoring was confounded by selection at the extreme low end. Students who failed naturally improve regardless of intervention intensity. When applied universally, intensive tutoring removes independent study time and reveals its true negative impact on moderately struggling students.
gold_rationale: The teacher's conclusion commits the regression to mean trap with intervention at extremes. Intensive tutoring was initially applied to students who failed completely—the extreme low performers who had nowhere to go but up. Their improvement was largely due to natural regression toward the mean, not the intervention's effectiveness. When applied universally to all struggling students, intensive tutoring revealed its true cost: reduced independent study time that many students need, causing overall performance to drop.

gold_rationale: The coach's conclusion commits the regression to mean trap with intervention at extremes. Their improvement was largely due to natural regression toward their true ability level, not the extra practice. The improvement metric is misleading because it compares different baselines. When applied universally, extra practice revealed its true cost: increased strain and fatigue that caused overall team performance to decline due to overtraining.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If feedback was assigned randomly, then improvement differences could be attributed to the feedback method itself.

wise_refusal: This is regression to the mean combined with intervention at extremes. The apparent success of intensive feedback was confounded by selection at the extreme low end—employees with poor reviews naturally improve regardless of feedback intensity. The improvement metric is misleading due to different denominators. gold_rationale: The manager's conclusion commits the regression to mean trap with intervention at extremes. Intensive feedback was initially given to employees after poor reviews—the extreme low performers who had nowhere to go but up. Their improvement was largely due to natural regression toward their true performance level, not the intensive feedback. The improvement metric is misleading because it compares different baselines. When applied universally, intensive feedback revealed its true cost: overwhelming well-performing employees with excessive criticism, making them confused and self-conscious, which decreased overall productivity.

scenario: A retail store notices 25% more customer complaints during holiday seasons. The manager concludes holiday stress makes customers more difficult and implements special training. However, holiday seasons have 50% more customers.
claim: Holiday stress makes customers more difficult and prone to complaints
label: NO
causal_structure: Holiday season increases customer volume which increases raw complaint count; complaint rate per customer may actually be lower.
key_insight: Raw complaint counts ignore base rate of customer exposure; more customers naturally means more complaints.
hidden_timestamp: What happens to the complaint rate per customer during the holiday season compared to non-holiday periods?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the complaint rate per customer is higher during holidays, then holiday stress may be making customers more difficult.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the complaint rate per customer is lower or unchanged during holidays, then the increase in complaints is simply due to more customers, not increased difficulty.

wise_refusal: This is base rate neglect. Holiday season has 50% more customers than average, but only 25% more complaints. The relevant metric is complaints per customer, not raw complaint count. The 'spike' in complaints simply reflects more customer interactions, not more difficult customers. In fact, the complaint rate per customer is actually lower during holidays.
gold_rationale: The manager's conclusion commits base rate neglect by focusing on raw complaint counts while ignoring customer volume. With 50% more customers during holidays but only 25% more complaints, the complaint rate per customer is actually lower (not higher) during holiday seasons. The increased complaint count simply reflects more customer interactions and purchase opportunities, not more difficult customer behavior due to holiday stress.

scenario: A school reports 20% more disciplinary incidents in the cafeteria than in classrooms. The principal concludes lunchtime is chaotic and increases supervision. However, the cafeteria serves 80% of students simultaneously.
claim: Lunchtime is more chaotic and problematic than classroom time
label: NO
causal_structure: Cafeteria concentrates 80% of students in one space while classrooms distribute them; higher student density naturally increases incident opportunities.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the incident rate per student is similar or lower in the cafeteria, the higher raw count is just due to more students being present, not increased chaos.

wise_refusal: This is base rate neglect. The cafeteria has 80% of students concentrated in one location, while classrooms distribute students across multiple smaller groups. The relevant metric is incidents per student-hour, not raw incident count. The 20% increase in incidents likely reflects normal interaction rates among a much larger concentrated population, not inherently chaotic behavior.
gold_rationale: The principal's conclusion commits base rate neglect by comparing raw incident counts between locations with vastly different student densities. The cafeteria concentrates 80% of students in one space during lunch, while classrooms distribute students across multiple smaller groups throughout the day. The 20% increase in cafeteria incidents likely reflects normal interaction and conflict rates among a much larger, concentrated population rather than inherently more chaotic behavior during lunchtime.

scenario: A city observes 35% more noise complaints in summer months. Officials conclude summer heat makes people more irritable and launch awareness campaigns. However, summer has 60% more outdoor events and open windows.
claim: Summer heat makes people more irritable and prone to noise complaints
label: NO
causal_structure: Summer increases both noise sources (outdoor events) and noise exposure (open windows); more noise opportunities naturally create more complaints.
key_insight: Raw complaint counts ignore increased noise exposure; more outdoor activity and open windows naturally amplify noise awareness.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If complaints are measured only as a raw count, the observed increase could be due to more noise sources, not more irritability.

wise_refusal: This is base rate neglect. Summer has 60% more outdoor events and open windows, but only 35% more noise complaints. The relevant consideration is complaints relative to noise exposure opportunities, not raw complaint count. The increase reflects more actual noise sources and greater sound transmission through open windows, not increased irritability from heat.
gold_rationale: The officials' conclusion commits base rate neglect by focusing on raw complaint counts while ignoring the dramatic increase in noise exposure during summer. With 60% more outdoor events and widespread open windows, there are significantly more noise sources and transmission pathways. The 35% increase in complaints actually represents a lower complaint rate relative to noise exposure opportunities, suggesting people may be more tolerant, not more irritable, during summer months.

scenario: A stock trader makes profitable trades 6 days in a row. They conclude they have found a winning strategy and will likely profit tomorrow. Statistical analysis shows daily returns are independent.
claim: A streak of profitable trades indicates a winning strategy that will continue
label: NO
causal_structure: Past trading results do not causally influence future independent market movements.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If daily returns are independent, past streaks do not affect future profit probability.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If there is a mechanism linking past and future performance, a streak could indicate a real strategy.

wise_refusal: This is an example of the Hot Hand Fallacy in trading. Because daily returns are independent, a streak does not causally increase the probability of future profits. The observed pattern is likely due to chance, not a winning strategy.
gold_rationale: The trader's conclusion commits the regression to the mean trap, specifically the Hot Hand Fallacy in trading contexts. While a 6-day winning streak feels meaningful and predictive, statistical analysis confirms that daily market returns are largely independent events. Past profitable trades do not causally influence future market movements or trade outcomes. The perceived pattern is illusory—humans naturally seek patterns in randomness and mistake temporary streaks for evidence of skill or strategy effectiveness.

scenario: A weather forecaster correctly predicts rain 4 days in a row. They declare they have a "hot streak" and will likely be correct tomorrow. Meteorological analysis shows daily weather patterns are independent.
claim: A streak of correct predictions indicates a hot streak that will continue
label: NO
causal_structure: Past prediction accuracy does not causally influence future independent weather events.
key_insight: Humans see patterns in randomness and mistake correlation for causation in independent events.
hidden_timestamp: Are daily weather patterns and prediction accuracy independent from day to day, or is there a causal link between past and future accuracy?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If daily weather patterns and prediction accuracy are independent, then past streaks do not affect future accuracy.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If there is a causal link between past and future accuracy, then a streak might indicate increased future accuracy.

wise_refusal: This is the Hot Hand Fallacy applied to weather forecasting. While intuitively compelling, meteorological analysis shows that daily weather patterns are largely independent events. A streak of 4 correct predictions does not causally increase the probability of tomorrow's accuracy. The correlation is illusory pattern-matching in what are independent atmospheric conditions.
gold_rationale: The forecaster's conclusion commits the regression to the mean trap, specifically the Hot Hand Fallacy in prediction contexts. While a 4-day streak of correct predictions feels meaningful and indicative of skill momentum, meteorological analysis confirms that daily weather patterns are largely independent events. Past prediction accuracy does not causally influence future atmospheric conditions or forecasting success. The perceived "hot streak" is illusory - humans naturally seek patterns in randomness and mistake temporary streaks for evidence of enhanced predictive ability.

scenario: People who wear the same lucky number report feeling more successful together. A numerology website claims numbers determine life outcomes. However, believers remember successes and forget failures.
claim: Lucky numbers determine life outcomes and success
label: NO
causal_structure: Belief (Z) drives both attention to lucky number (X) and perception of success (Y).
key_insight: People remember hits and forget misses; numbers have no causal mechanism for life outcomes.
hidden_timestamp: Do people who do not believe in lucky numbers but are assigned one at random also report higher success?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If non-believers assigned a lucky number do not report higher success, the association is likely due to belief-driven bias.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If non-believers assigned a lucky number do report higher success, there may be an effect beyond belief, but further investigation is needed.

wise_refusal: This is an associational claim driven by confounding from confirmation bias. People who believe in numerology remember cases where their lucky number 'worked' and forget cases where it didn't. The number itself has no causal mechanism to affect life outcomes or success.
gold_rationale: The numerology website's claim commits the confounding trap driven by confirmation bias. People who believe in lucky numbers selectively remember instances where positive events coincided with their number while forgetting negative events or neutral outcomes. Numbers have no causal mechanism to influence life events or success. The belief system itself drives both attention to the supposed lucky number and biased perception of outcomes, creating an illusory correlation through selective memory and interpretation.

scenario: People who consult the same fortune teller report feeling more confident about their futures. A psychic service claims predictions determine outcomes. However, believers remember accurate predictions and forget inaccurate ones.
claim: Fortune teller predictions determine future outcomes
label: NO
causal_structure: Belief (Z) drives both attention to predictions (X) and perception of outcomes (Y).
key_insight: People remember hits and forget misses; predictions have no causal mechanism for future outcomes.
hidden_timestamp: Is there any mechanism by which the fortune teller's predictions could directly influence future outcomes, independent of belief or selective memory?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If there is no mechanism and selective memory is present, the association is spurious due to confounding by belief.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If there is a direct mechanism by which predictions influence outcomes, then the claim could be valid.

wise_refusal: This is an associational claim driven by confirmation bias. People who believe in psychic predictions remember cases where predictions 'came true' and forget cases where they didn't. The prediction has no causal mechanism to affect future outcomes. Belief drives both attention to the fortune teller and selective perception of confirming events.
gold_rationale: The psychic service's claim commits the confounding trap driven by confirmation bias. People who believe in fortune telling selectively remember instances where predictions seemed to come true while forgetting inaccurate predictions or reinterpreting neutral events as confirmations. Predictions have no causal mechanism to influence future events or outcomes. The belief system itself drives both attention to the fortune teller's statements and biased interpretation of subsequent events, creating an illusory correlation through selective memory and confirmation seeking.

scenario: A survey finds that people who regularly attend yoga classes report lower stress levels than those who do not attend yoga classes. The survey was conducted among members of a local wellness center.
claim: Attending yoga classes causes lower stress levels.
label: NO
causal_structure: Only individuals who are members of the wellness center were surveyed, which may select for people already motivated to reduce stress or engage in healthy behaviors (Z), creating a spurious association between attending yoga (X) and stress levels (Y).
key_insight: Selection bias can create misleading associations when the sample is not representative of the general population.
hidden_timestamp: Were people who do not attend yoga classes but are not wellness center members included in the survey?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If only wellness center members were surveyed, the association may be due to selection bias.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the survey included a random sample from the general population, the association would be more credible.

wise_refusal: Causal inference is not justified because selection bias (W1) may explain the observed association; the sample is restricted to wellness center members, who may differ systematically from the general population.
gold_rationale: The claim that attending yoga classes causes lower stress levels is not justified because the observed association may be due to selection bias: only wellness center members were surveyed, and these individuals may already be more health-conscious or motivated to reduce stress (Z). Therefore, the sample is not representative, and the association between X and Y may not reflect a true causal effect.

scenario: A group of adults is randomly assigned to either drink a cup of green tea every morning or not, for three months. At the end of the period, those who drank green tea have significantly lower average blood pressure compared to the control group.
claim: Drinking green tea every morning causes lower blood pressure in adults.
label: YES
causal_structure: Random assignment to green tea or control ensures that confounders like diet and exercise are balanced, so the observed association reflects the causal effect of green tea on blood pressure.
key_insight: Randomized controlled trials provide strong evidence for causality by eliminating confounding.
hidden_timestamp: Was the assignment to drink green tea truly random and adhered to throughout the study?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If assignment was truly random and followed, the causal claim is justified.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If assignment was not random or not followed, confounding could explain the result.

wise_refusal: This is a valid causal claim because randomization in an RCT balances confounders, supporting a direct causal interpretation.
gold_rationale: Because participants were randomly assigned to drink green tea or not, confounders like dietary habits and physical activity (Z) are expected to be evenly distributed between groups. The observed lower blood pressure (Y) in the green tea group can thus be attributed to the intervention (X), satisfying the requirements for a valid causal inference at the association level.

scenario: A survey finds that people who drink herbal tea every day report lower stress levels than those who do not.
claim: Drinking herbal tea causes lower stress levels.
label: AMBIGUOUS
causal_structure: X and Y are associated in survey data, but Z (lifestyle or stress management habits) could confound the relationship.
key_insight: Association alone does not establish causality when key confounders are unmeasured.
hidden_timestamp: Did the survey control for participants' overall lifestyle or other stress management practices?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the survey controlled for lifestyle and stress management habits, the association may be more likely to reflect causality.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the survey did not control for these confounders, the association could be spurious.

wise_refusal: A causal conclusion cannot be drawn because the association may be confounded by unmeasured factors such as lifestyle or stress management habits.
gold_rationale: While the data show an association between drinking herbal tea and lower stress levels, it is unclear whether this is causal or due to confounding by other factors (Z), such as individuals with healthier lifestyles being both more likely to drink herbal tea and to have lower stress. Without information on whether these confounders were addressed, the causal claim remains ambiguous.

scenario: People who regularly eat breakfast are observed to have higher productivity at work compared to those who skip breakfast. The data comes from a large workplace survey.
claim: Eating breakfast causes higher productivity at work.
label: AMBIGUOUS
causal_structure: X may influence Y, but Z variables like discipline and health could confound the association; the direction and presence of causality are unclear without more information.
key_insight: Association does not guarantee causation when key confounders are unmeasured.
hidden_timestamp: Were participants randomly assigned to eat breakfast, or did they self-select based on their habits?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If participants were randomly assigned, the association would more likely reflect causality.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If participants self-selected, the observed association could be due to confounding factors like discipline or health.

wise_refusal: We cannot conclude causality because the study design and confounding variables are unclear; more information is needed to rule out alternative explanations.
gold_rationale: While there is an observed association between eating breakfast and higher productivity, it is ambiguous whether this reflects causality. Confounders such as morning routine discipline or overall health could influence both breakfast habits and productivity. Without knowing if the assignment to eat breakfast was random or if confounders were controlled, we cannot justify the causal claim.

scenario: A group of adults is randomly assigned to either take a daily 30-minute walk or not change their routine for three months. At the end of the period, those who walked daily report significantly lower stress levels compared to the control group.
claim: Taking a daily 30-minute walk causes a reduction in stress levels.
label: YES
causal_structure: Random assignment ensures that confounders like baseline stress and lifestyle are balanced, so any difference in stress levels can be attributed to the walking intervention.
key_insight: Randomized controlled trials provide strong evidence for causal claims by eliminating confounding.
hidden_timestamp: Were participants randomly assigned to the walking and control groups?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If assignment was random, the observed reduction in stress can be causally attributed to daily walking.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If assignment was not random, confounding could explain the association and causality cannot be inferred.

wise_refusal: This is a valid causal claim because random assignment in an RCT controls for confounding variables, supporting a direct causal interpretation.
gold_rationale: Because participants were randomly assigned to walk or not, confounders such as baseline stress and lifestyle factors (Z) are balanced between groups. The observed reduction in stress levels (Y) among those who walked (X) can therefore be causally attributed to the intervention, satisfying the requirements for a valid association-level causal claim.

scenario: A city unexpectedly banned all non-electric scooters due to a sudden change in environmental regulations. Researchers compared the rates of respiratory complaints in this city to a similar nearby city where no such ban occurred.
claim: Banning non-electric scooters causes a reduction in respiratory complaints.
label: YES
causal_structure: An exogenous policy shock (ban on non-electric scooters) in one city allows for a natural experiment, comparing outcomes with a similar control city to identify the effect of the ban on respiratory complaints.
key_insight: A sudden, externally imposed policy change enables strong causal inference from observed associations.
hidden_timestamp: Was the ban implemented at the same time as any other major environmental changes?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If no other major changes occurred, the observed reduction in complaints can be attributed to the scooter ban.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If other changes happened simultaneously, the effect cannot be solely attributed to the scooter ban.

wise_refusal: This is a strong case for causality because the exogenous policy change acts as a natural experiment, minimizing confounding and supporting the claim.
gold_rationale: The sudden, externally imposed ban on non-electric scooters provides a natural experiment (S2), as the treatment is plausibly exogenous to other factors affecting respiratory health. Comparing the treated city to a similar control city allows for a credible estimate of the effect of the ban (X) on respiratory complaints (Y), especially if confounders like air pollution from other sources and population age distribution (Z) are accounted for. The association observed is justified as causal due to the identification strategy.

scenario: A city allocates parking permits to residents using a random lottery system due to limited availability. Researchers compare the commute times of those who won the lottery to those who did not.
claim: Winning a parking permit causes a reduction in daily commute time.
label: YES
causal_structure: Random assignment of parking permits via lottery ensures that, on average, winners and non-winners are comparable on confounders, so differences in commute time can be causally attributed to permit access.
key_insight: Randomized lotteries can provide strong causal evidence even in complex real-world settings.
hidden_timestamp: Were all applicants equally likely to win the parking permit lottery, regardless of their baseline commute time?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If all applicants had equal odds, the observed difference in commute time is likely causal.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the lottery was biased toward certain applicants, the causal claim may not hold.

wise_refusal: This claim is justified because the lottery provides quasi-random assignment, minimizing confounding and supporting a causal interpretation.
gold_rationale: The use of a random lottery to allocate parking permits means that, on average, winners and non-winners should not differ systematically in unobserved confounders like work location or car ownership. Therefore, any observed reduction in commute time among winners can be causally attributed to receiving a permit. This is a strong example of quasi-random assignment (S3), which supports the causal claim at the association level.

scenario: Researchers wanted to know if using blue light blocking glasses before bed improves sleep quality. In a controlled study, participants were randomly assigned to wear blue light blocking glasses or regular glasses for two weeks, while all other factors like bedtime, caffeine intake, and screen time were kept constant. The group with blue light blocking glasses reported significantly better sleep quality.
claim: Wearing blue light blocking glasses before bed causes improved sleep quality.
label: YES

X.name: Wearing blue light blocking glasses before bed

causal_structure: Random assignment to blue light blocking glasses versus regular glasses, with all other relevant factors held constant, allows for isolation of the effect of X on Y.
key_insight: Holding other factors constant isolates the effect of blue light blocking glasses on sleep quality.
hidden_timestamp: Were there any other changes in participants' routines besides the glasses?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If no other changes occurred, the improvement in sleep quality can be attributed to the glasses.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If other changes occurred, the effect might be due to those factors instead.

wise_refusal: This study used controlled ablation, holding other variables constant, so the evidence supports a causal claim.
gold_rationale: Because participants were randomly assigned to wear blue light blocking or regular glasses and all other relevant factors (bedtime, caffeine intake, screen time) were held constant, the observed improvement in sleep quality can be causally attributed to the glasses. This is a classic controlled ablation design (S4), which isolates the effect of X (glasses) on Y (sleep quality) by controlling for Z (potential confounders).

scenario: A group of adults participated in a study where their daily coffee intake was measured, and their alertness levels were tracked throughout the day. Researchers found that as participants drank more cups of coffee, their measured alertness increased proportionally.
claim: Increasing coffee consumption causes higher alertness levels in adults.
label: YES
causal_structure: The study observes a dose-response relationship between coffee intake (X) and alertness (Y), supported by a plausible biological mechanism: caffeine blocks adenosine receptors, reducing drowsiness and increasing alertness.
key_insight: A clear dose-response and known mechanism support a causal link between coffee and alertness.
hidden_timestamp: Was the increase in alertness consistent across individuals with different baseline sleep quality?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the effect holds regardless of sleep quality, the causal claim is further strengthened.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If only those with poor sleep benefit, the effect may be moderated by sleep quality.

wise_refusal: The observed dose-response relationship, combined with a well-understood biological mechanism, provides strong association-level evidence supporting the causal claim.
gold_rationale: The evidence includes both a graded (dose-response) increase in alertness with higher coffee intake and a known mechanism (caffeine's effect on adenosine receptors). While confounders like sleep quality and metabolism rate exist, the consistent association and mechanistic explanation justify the causal claim at the association level.

scenario: A city wants to determine if using noise-canceling headphones at work increases productivity. Some offices have a strict policy assigning headphones randomly to employees, while others do not. Researchers use the random assignment policy as an instrumental variable to estimate the effect of headphone use on productivity.
claim: Using noise-canceling headphones at work causes an increase in employee productivity.
label: YES

X.name: Use of noise-canceling headphones at work

causal_structure: The random assignment policy acts as an instrumental variable affecting headphone use (X), which in turn affects productivity (Y), while being independent of confounders like motivation or office environment.
key_insight: A valid instrumental variable can reveal causal effects even when confounding exists.
hidden_timestamp: Was the random assignment of headphones truly independent of employee characteristics?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If assignment was truly random, the causal claim is justified.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If assignment was not random, confounding may bias the result.

wise_refusal: The use of a valid instrumental variable (random assignment policy) supports a causal interpretation, as it isolates the effect of headphone use from confounders.
gold_rationale: Because the random assignment of noise-canceling headphones serves as a valid instrument, it allows the estimation of the causal effect of headphone use (X) on productivity (Y) while controlling for unmeasured confounders (Z) such as baseline motivation and office environment. This supports the claim that headphone use causes increased productivity.

scenario: A city implemented a new public transportation line in one part of town but not in a similar neighboring area. Researchers compared average commute times before and after the change in both areas and found that commute times decreased significantly only in the area with the new line.
claim: Introducing the new public transportation line caused a reduction in average commute times.
label: YES

X.name: introduction of new public transportation line

causal_structure: A difference-in-differences approach compares changes in commute times over time between the area with the new line (treatment) and the similar area without it (control), assuming parallel trends.
key_insight: Comparing changes over time in treated and control areas helps isolate the causal effect of the intervention.
hidden_timestamp: Were there any other major changes in either area during the study period that could affect commute times?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If no other major changes occurred, the reduction in commute times can be attributed to the new line.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If other changes occurred, the observed effect could be confounded and not solely due to the new line.

wise_refusal: The evidence supports causality because the difference-in-differences design compares changes in both areas, controlling for time trends and area-specific factors.
gold_rationale: The difference-in-differences methodology leverages the introduction of the public transportation line in one area and not the other, comparing before-and-after changes in both. This helps control for confounders (Z) like baseline commute patterns and area-specific factors, supporting the claim that X (the new line) caused Y (reduced commute times), provided no other major changes occurred.

scenario: A city government implements a new recycling incentive program, awarding households with a bonus if their recycling rate exceeds a certain threshold. Researchers compare households just above and just below the cutoff to assess the effect of the incentive on recycling rates.
claim: Receiving the recycling incentive causes households to recycle more.
label: YES
causal_structure: A regression discontinuity design compares households just above and just below the recycling incentive threshold, assuming households near the cutoff are similar except for receiving the incentive.
key_insight: Regression discontinuity at a policy cutoff can reveal causal effects when assignment is as-good-as-random near the threshold.
hidden_timestamp: Were there any other policy changes or events occurring exactly at the recycling incentive threshold?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If no other changes occurred at the threshold, the observed jump in recycling rates is likely due to the incentive.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If other changes coincided with the threshold, the effect cannot be solely attributed to the incentive.

wise_refusal: The regression discontinuity design provides strong evidence for causality because households just above and below the threshold are comparable, isolating the effect of the incentive.
gold_rationale: The use of a regression discontinuity design (S8) means that assignment to the recycling incentive is determined by a strict cutoff, making households near the threshold similar in all respects except for the treatment (X: receiving the incentive). This design controls for confounders (Z: household size, environmental attitudes) as long as there is no manipulation around the cutoff or other coincident interventions. The observed difference in Y (recycling rate) can thus be causally attributed to X, supporting the claim.

scenario: A survey finds that people who drink herbal tea every evening tend to report better sleep quality than those who do not.
claim: Drinking herbal tea in the evening causes better sleep quality.
label: AMBIGUOUS

X.name: Drinking herbal tea in the evening

causal_structure: X may affect Y, but Z (such as relaxation routines or sleep disorders) could confound the observed association between herbal tea and sleep quality.
key_insight: Association does not guarantee causation when key confounders are unmeasured.
hidden_timestamp: Do people who drink herbal tea also engage in other relaxing activities before bed?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If herbal tea drinkers also practice other relaxation routines, the association may be due to those routines rather than the tea.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If herbal tea is the only difference and no other routines or sleep disorders differ, the association may reflect a causal effect.

wise_refusal: A causal conclusion cannot be drawn without knowing whether other relaxation routines or sleep disorders differ between groups; the association is ambiguous due to possible confounding.
gold_rationale: While there is an observed association between drinking herbal tea and better sleep quality, it is unclear whether this is due to the tea itself or to other factors such as evening relaxation routines or the presence of sleep disorders. Without controlling for these confounders (Z), we cannot determine if X truly causes Y. Thus, the causal claim is ambiguous.

scenario: A survey finds that people who regularly eat breakfast tend to report higher energy levels throughout the day compared to those who skip breakfast.
claim: Eating breakfast causes higher daily energy levels.
label: AMBIGUOUS
causal_structure: X (eating breakfast) may influence Y (energy levels), but Z (sleep quality, health status) could confound the association; the direction and existence of causality is unclear without further information.
key_insight: Association does not guarantee causation when key confounders are unmeasured.
hidden_timestamp: Did the survey control for participants' sleep quality and overall health status?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the survey controlled for these confounders, the association might reflect a causal effect.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If these confounders were not controlled, the association could be spurious.

wise_refusal: A causal conclusion cannot be drawn without knowing whether confounders like sleep quality and health status were accounted for.
gold_rationale: While there is an observed association between eating breakfast and higher energy levels, it is ambiguous whether eating breakfast itself causes increased energy. Unmeasured confounders such as sleep quality and overall health status could explain the association. Without evidence that these factors were controlled, the causal claim remains unjustified.

scenario: An office wellness team runs a randomized trial during morning break for two weeks: on each day, participating employees are randomly assigned to receive either a cup of caffeinated coffee or a similar-tasting decaf beverage. Immediately after the break, all participants complete the same short alertness questionnaire about the following hour. Averaged over the study period, the caffeinated-coffee group reports higher alertness than the decaf group.
claim: Drinking caffeinated coffee during the morning break increases office workers' alertness in the following hour.
label: YES

X.name: Receiving caffeinated coffee during morning break (randomized)

Y.name: Self-reported alertness in the following hour

causal_structure: X is randomized (coffee vs decaf), so any systematic difference in Y between groups supports a causal effect of X on Y; Z may affect Y but should not systematically differ by X under randomization.
key_insight: Random assignment with a placebo-like control makes confounding unlikely, so the observed difference supports the causal claim.
hidden_timestamp: Were employees randomly assigned to receive caffeinated coffee versus a control (decaf/placebo) during morning break?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the randomized caffeinated-coffee group reports higher subsequent alertness than the control group, the causal claim is supported (YES).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the randomized groups show no difference (or the caffeinated group is lower), this study does not support the causal claim (NO).

wise_refusal: Supported: because employees were randomly assigned to caffeinated coffee versus a decaf control and the caffeinated group reports higher alertness afterward, the scenario provides experimental evidence consistent with coffee increasing alertness.
gold_rationale: This is S1 (RCT): random assignment and a control condition directly support the causal claim given the reported higher alertness in the treated group.

scenario: A company pilots a controlled policy change for one month: some teams are instructed to implement two scheduled 5-minute breaks each afternoon, while matched teams keep their usual routines (no scheduled breaks). Teams keep the same projects and deadlines during the month. At the end of each workday, employees complete the same short fatigue survey. The break-policy teams report lower end-of-day fatigue on average than the teams without scheduled breaks.
claim: Scheduling regular short breaks during the workday reduces end-of-day fatigue among office workers.
label: YES

X.name: Having scheduled short breaks during the workday (policy change)

Z: Manager flexibility / break culture by team

trap.subtype_name: Change X while holding other factors constant

causal_structure: Teams are matched and asked to keep similar projects/deadlines while only break scheduling differs; this controlled ablation supports X -> Y if the matching/controls are credible.
key_insight: When the policy is the main systematic difference between comparable teams, lower fatigue is evidence consistent with a causal effect.
hidden_timestamp: Were the break-policy and control teams comparable (matched) and operating under similar project/deadline conditions during the month?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If matched teams truly faced comparable workload/deadlines and only the scheduled-break policy differed, then lower fatigue in break teams supports the causal claim (YES).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If teams differed substantially in workload, management, or deadlines in ways not controlled, the observed difference could be confounded and the causal claim is not supported (AMBIGUOUS).

wise_refusal: Supported conditional on the stated matching: the scenario claims comparable teams with similar projects/deadlines except for the break policy, and the break-policy teams report lower fatigue—consistent with breaks reducing fatigue.
gold_rationale: This matches S4 (controlled ablation): the intervention toggles scheduled breaks while holding other conditions similar, and the reported lower fatigue supports the causal claim as stated.

scenario: A survey of public transportation users asks whether they listen to music during their commute and how stressed they feel during the commute. The survey summary does not clearly describe whether respondents were sampled from morning commutes, evening commutes, or both. Results show that respondents who report listening to music also report lower commute stress.
claim: Listening to music during a commute reduces stress among public transportation users.
label: AMBIGUOUS

Z: Sampling frame / commute time-of-day included (morning vs evening vs both)

causal_structure: If commute time-of-day influences both music listening and stress, then an unclear sampling frame makes it unclear what population the X–Y relationship refers to and whether it generalizes.
key_insight: Without a clear sampling frame/target population, even a reported correlation can’t cleanly support a causal claim.
hidden_timestamp: Which commute periods were included in the survey sample (morning, evening, or both), and is the claim intended to generalize to all public-transport commutes?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the survey sampled a well-defined population (e.g., all public-transport commutes across times) and still found lower stress among music listeners, the claim would remain uncertain causally but the association would be well-defined (AMBIGUOUS without causal identification).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the sampling frame is restricted/unknown while the claim is about all users, the claim is underspecified and remains AMBIGUOUS.

wise_refusal: Ambiguous: the survey reports lower stress among music listeners, but it doesn’t specify the sampling frame (morning/evening/both). Without knowing what population is represented (and given this is observational), the causal claim can’t be confidently evaluated.
gold_rationale: Because the sampling frame is unclear and the evidence is purely observational, the causal claim is not clearly supported; the case is ambiguous.

scenario: A company analyzes only employees who both attended an annual innovation workshop and received high performance reviews. Within this restricted group, they observe that employees who work overtime tend to receive more promotions. The analysis does not include employees who did not attend the workshop or did not receive high reviews.
claim: Working overtime causes employees to receive more promotions.
label: NO

Z: Selection into the analyzed sample (attended workshop AND high review)

causal_structure: The analysis conditions on a selected subset (workshop attendance + high review). Conditioning on selection related to advancement can induce or distort an overtime–promotion association, so the observed within-sample relationship does not support the causal claim.
key_insight: Conditioning on a selected subgroup can manufacture or distort correlations, making a causal conclusion invalid.
hidden_timestamp: Is the reported overtime–promotion pattern computed only within a subgroup defined by workshop attendance and high reviews (i.e., conditioned on selection)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the relationship were evaluated on the full employee population (without conditioning on workshop attendance/high review) and still held after appropriate controls, the causal claim could be assessed (AMBIGUOUS given this information is absent).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Given the analysis conditions on a highly selected subset, the observed association can be selection-induced and does not support the causal claim (NO).

wise_refusal: No: the company computes the relationship only within a selected subgroup (workshop attendees with high reviews). Conditioning on selection can distort the overtime–promotion relationship, so the evidence described does not justify the causal claim.
gold_rationale: This is W1 selection bias: conditioning on a selected subset can induce biased X–Y relationships, so the causal claim is not supported by the described analysis.

scenario: A survey is conducted only among employees who received a promotion in the past year. Within this promoted group, those who report working overtime also report higher job satisfaction than those who were promoted without overtime. No non-promoted employees are surveyed.
claim: Working overtime increases job satisfaction among employees.
label: NO

Z: Selection into the survey (only promoted employees)

trap.subtype_name: Surveying only a selected subset (promoted employees)

causal_structure: The sample is restricted to promoted employees; conditioning on promotion can distort the overtime–satisfaction relationship and prevents inferring a causal effect in the overall employee population.
key_insight: A subgroup-only survey can’t justify a population-wide causal conclusion.
hidden_timestamp: Does the survey include only promoted employees (i.e., does it condition on promotion status)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the survey sampled all employees (promoted and not) and overtime preceded satisfaction measurement, then the relationship could be evaluated (AMBIGUOUS because those data are not provided).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Given the survey samples only promoted employees, selection can distort the relationship and the causal claim is not supported (NO).

wise_refusal: No: because the survey includes only promoted employees, the observed overtime–satisfaction relationship may be selection-driven and does not support the causal claim for all employees.
gold_rationale: W1 selection bias: sampling only a selected subgroup (promoted employees) prevents valid causal inference about all employees.

scenario: A survey is conducted among people who have voluntarily resigned from their jobs within the last month. Respondents are asked about their job satisfaction before leaving, and most report low satisfaction. The survey includes only recent quitters.
claim: Low job satisfaction causes employees to quit their jobs.
label: NO

Z: Selection into the sample (only people who quit are surveyed)

causal_structure: Because only quitters are observed (selection on Y), the dataset cannot compare satisfaction levels among non-quitters, so it cannot support a causal claim about quitting.
key_insight: Sampling only outcome cases prevents estimating whether X differs between those with and without Y.
hidden_timestamp: Does the survey include employees who did not quit (non-quitters) for comparison?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If both quitters and non-quitters were surveyed and satisfaction was measured before quitting, then the relationship could be evaluated (AMBIGUOUS given this evidence is absent).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Given only quitters are sampled, the causal claim is not supported (NO).

wise_refusal: No: surveying only people who quit provides no comparison group of non-quitters, so the evidence cannot support the causal claim that low satisfaction causes quitting.
gold_rationale: W1 selection bias: selection on the outcome (only quitters observed) prevents valid inference about the satisfaction–quitting relationship in the full employee population.

scenario: A survey is conducted among employees who were promoted. Within that promoted group, those who attended leadership workshops report higher job satisfaction than those who did not. Only promoted employees were invited to the survey.
claim: Attending leadership workshops increases job satisfaction among employees.
label: NO

Z: Selection into the survey (only promoted employees)

causal_structure: The association is estimated only among promoted employees; conditioning on promotion can bias the observed relationship between workshops and satisfaction relative to the full workforce.
key_insight: Evidence from a selected subgroup can’t justify a causal claim about everyone.
hidden_timestamp: Are non-promoted employees included in the survey used to support the claim?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the analysis included a representative employee sample (promoted and not) and workshop attendance preceded satisfaction measurement, the causal claim could be assessed (AMBIGUOUS given missing evidence).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Given the survey includes only promoted employees, selection may distort the relationship and the causal claim is not supported (NO).

wise_refusal: No: because the survey is restricted to promoted employees, the observed workshop–satisfaction pattern may be selection-driven and does not support a causal effect for all employees.
gold_rationale: W1 selection bias: subgroup-only sampling (conditioning on promotion) can distort relationships and prevents valid causal inference about the entire employee population.

scenario: A survey is sent to employees after promotion decisions are announced. Among respondents who were promoted, many report working longer hours after the promotion; employees who were not promoted report fewer hours. The survey does not record hours worked before the promotion decision.
claim: Working longer hours increases an employee's chance of being promoted.
label: NO

X.name: Working longer hours (measured after promotion decisions)

Z: Post-promotion role demands / new responsibilities (promotion can increase hours)

causal_structure: Y (promotion) occurs before X is measured; promotion can increase responsibilities and hours (Y -> X), so the observed pattern can reflect reverse causation rather than X -> Y.
key_insight: If the exposure is measured after the outcome, the direction can be reversed.
hidden_timestamp: Were hours measured before or after the promotion decision?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If hours were measured before promotion decisions (and promotions occurred later), the relationship could be evaluated (AMBIGUOUS without additional controls).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Given hours are measured after promotions are decided, the evidence is consistent with promotion causing longer hours, so the causal claim is not supported (NO).

wise_refusal: No: because hours are measured only after promotions are decided, the observed relationship can be explained by promotion increasing hours (reverse causation), so the evidence does not support the causal claim.
gold_rationale: W9 reverse causation: the temporal ordering is inconsistent with X causing Y in the described data; instead Y can cause measured X.

scenario: A company finds that, overall, remote workers have lower average performance scores than office workers. But when the data is split by department, remote workers in each department have higher performance scores than their in-office peers. Departments differ in size and baseline performance, and remote-work rates vary by department.
claim: Working remotely reduces employee performance.
label: NO

Z: Department (composition differs; remote-work rates vary by department)

causal_structure: Z (department) affects both X and Y. The aggregate relationship differs from (and reverses) the within-department relationship, so the aggregate comparison is misleading for a causal claim.
key_insight: If every subgroup shows the opposite pattern, the aggregate conclusion is a Simpson’s paradox trap.
hidden_timestamp: Does the direction of the remote–performance relationship reverse when stratifying by department?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the claim were strictly about the aggregate descriptive pattern only, it could describe the combined data but still would not establish causality (AMBIGUOUS for a causal claim).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the claim is interpreted as a general causal effect across comparable employees (within department), it is contradicted because within each department remote workers score higher; thus the causal claim is not supported (NO).

wise_refusal: No: this is Simpson’s paradox—overall averages suggest remote workers score lower, but within every department remote workers score higher. Aggregating across departments yields a misleading basis for a causal claim.
gold_rationale: W8 Simpson’s paradox: department composition drives the reversal; the aggregate pattern does not support the stated causal conclusion.

scenario: A randomized study at an office provides participants with either caffeinated coffee or decaf each morning for one week, assigned at random. Workers then rate their alertness during the workday using the same survey each day. The caffeinated group reports higher average alertness than the decaf group.
claim: Drinking caffeinated coffee in the morning increases office workers' alertness during the workday.
label: YES

X.name: Receiving caffeinated coffee in the morning (randomized)

causal_structure: X is randomized (caffeinated vs decaf), so differences in Y support a causal effect of caffeine on alertness; Z may affect Y but should balance across arms under randomization.
key_insight: Randomization + control provides direct evidence consistent with a causal effect.
hidden_timestamp: Was coffee (caffeinated vs control) randomly assigned before measuring alertness?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the randomized caffeinated group reports higher average alertness than the control group, the causal claim is supported (YES).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the randomized groups show no difference, the study does not support the causal claim (NO).

wise_refusal: Supported: participants were randomly assigned to caffeinated coffee versus a decaf control and the caffeinated group reports higher alertness, consistent with coffee increasing alertness.
gold_rationale: S1 (RCT): random assignment and the reported difference support the causal claim.

scenario: A company reviews employee satisfaction scores and finds that, overall, remote workers report lower satisfaction than in-office workers. However, when the data is split by department, remote workers in each department consistently report higher satisfaction than their in-office colleagues. The overall trend reverses within departmental subgroups.
claim: Working remotely reduces employee satisfaction.
label: NO

Z: Department (composition differs; remote-work rates vary by department)

causal_structure: Department influences both remote-work prevalence and satisfaction. The aggregate relationship reverses within each department, so the aggregate comparison is misleading for a causal claim.
key_insight: A single aggregate trend can be the opposite of every subgroup trend (Simpson’s paradox).
hidden_timestamp: Does the remote–satisfaction relationship reverse when stratifying by department?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the claim were only a descriptive statement about the aggregate average, it could describe the combined dataset but would not establish causality (AMBIGUOUS for a causal claim).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the claim is interpreted as a general causal effect among comparable employees (within department), it is contradicted because within every department remote workers report higher satisfaction; thus the causal claim is not supported (NO).

wise_refusal: No: this is Simpson’s paradox—overall remote workers report lower satisfaction, but within each department remote workers report higher satisfaction. The aggregate pattern is misleading and does not support the causal claim.
gold_rationale: W8 Simpson’s paradox: the aggregate association reverses within strata, so the causal claim is not supported by the evidence described.

scenario: A survey asks office workers whether they drink coffee and how alert they feel in the afternoon. The survey does not clarify whether “afternoon alertness” was rated on a day when they had already consumed coffee, nor whether “drinking coffee” means daily coffee, occasional coffee, or coffee specifically that day.
claim: Drinking coffee increases afternoon alertness among office workers.
label: AMBIGUOUS

X.name: Coffee consumption (unclear: frequency vs that-day use)

Z: Measurement ambiguity: unclear definition and timing for X and Y

causal_structure: Because X and Y are not operationalized (what counts as coffee use and when Y is measured relative to coffee), the intended X–Y relationship is not well-defined, so a causal claim cannot be evaluated.
key_insight: If X/Y aren’t defined, you can’t even tell what causal question is being asked.
hidden_timestamp: Does X refer to coffee consumed that same day before the afternoon rating, or general coffee-drinking frequency—and when exactly is Y measured relative to coffee intake?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If X is clearly defined as coffee consumed before the afternoon rating on the same day and Y is measured afterward, then the causal question is well-posed but still not answered by the provided summary (AMBIGUOUS).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If X/Y remain undefined with unclear timing/frequency, the causal claim is not well-posed (AMBIGUOUS).

wise_refusal: Ambiguous: the survey doesn’t define whether X is that-day coffee use or general frequency, and it doesn’t anchor Y relative to coffee timing. Without clear variable definitions, the causal claim can’t be evaluated.
gold_rationale: Key measurement/operationalization details are missing, so the causal claim cannot be reliably interpreted and remains ambiguous.

scenario: A company survey asks respondents whether they work from home and to rate their job satisfaction. The results summary does not report the composition of respondents (e.g., full-time employees vs contractors vs part-time), nor whether response rates differ across these groups.
claim: Working from home increases job satisfaction among employees at the company.
label: AMBIGUOUS

Z: Unclear respondent composition/representativeness (full-time vs contractor vs part-time; possible differential response)

trap.subtype_name: Who is in the dataset is unclear

causal_structure: If different worker types differ in both WFH prevalence and satisfaction, then an unknown sample composition/response pattern makes it unclear what population the X–Y relationship refers to and whether it supports the claim.
key_insight: If you don’t know who responded, you don’t know what claim the data can support.
hidden_timestamp: Do we know which worker types responded (and in what proportions) and whether the survey represents employees at the company?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the survey response is representative of employees (similar response rates across worker types) and X precedes Y measurement, then the causal question is clearer but the causal claim still isn’t established by a simple survey summary (AMBIGUOUS).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If respondent composition/representativeness is unknown, the claim about 'employees at the company' is underspecified and remains AMBIGUOUS.

wise_refusal: Ambiguous: the survey doesn’t report who responded or whether the sample represents employees. Without a clear sampling frame/composition, the causal claim can’t be evaluated reliably.
gold_rationale: Because the respondent population is not specified and the evidence is observational, the causal claim cannot be confidently supported and remains ambiguous.

scenario: A gym has limited spots in popular group fitness classes. New members who sign up are assigned to class spots by lottery when demand exceeds capacity; those who do not win a spot work out alone. After one month, both groups complete the same motivation-to-exercise survey. Members who won the class lottery report higher motivation on average than those who did not.
claim: Attending group fitness classes increases motivation to exercise among gym members.
label: YES

X.name: Attending group fitness classes (lottery assignment when oversubscribed)

causal_structure: Lottery allocation among interested applicants makes winners and non-winners comparable in expectation; differences in Y support a causal effect of attending classes on motivation.
key_insight: A lottery creates a credible counterfactual comparison group.
hidden_timestamp: Were class spots allocated quasi-randomly (by lottery) among members who wanted to join when demand exceeded capacity?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If lottery winners (attendees) report higher motivation than lottery non-winners after one month, the causal claim is supported (YES).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If there is no difference between lottery winners and non-winners, the causal claim is not supported by this setup (NO).

wise_refusal: Supported: because class spots were assigned by lottery among interested new members and winners report higher motivation than non-winners, the scenario provides quasi-random evidence consistent with classes increasing motivation.
gold_rationale: S3 lottery/quasi-random assignment: random allocation among applicants supports the causal claim given the reported higher motivation among winners.

scenario: A randomized study of office workers assigns participants each morning for two weeks to either receive caffeinated coffee or a similar-tasting decaf beverage (control). Later in the day, everyone rates their alertness using the same survey. Across the study, the caffeinated group reports higher alertness on average than the control group.
claim: Drinking caffeinated coffee increases alertness during the workday among office workers.
label: YES
causal_structure: Random assignment to caffeinated vs decaf creates comparable groups; higher alertness in the caffeinated group supports a causal effect of caffeine on alertness.
key_insight: An RCT provides direct evidence for the causal claim.
hidden_timestamp: Was coffee exposure randomized with a control group before measuring alertness?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the randomized caffeinated group reports higher alertness than the control group, the causal claim is supported (YES).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If randomized groups do not differ, the study does not support the causal claim (NO).

wise_refusal: Supported: the scenario describes random assignment to caffeinated coffee versus a decaf control and reports higher alertness in the treated group, consistent with a causal effect.
gold_rationale: S1 (RCT): random assignment and the reported difference support the causal claim.

scenario: A university sleep clinic studies graduate students during a finals week. Students keep their usual schedules but are randomly assigned to one of three caffeine doses at 9:00am each day for five days: 0 mg (decaf), 100 mg (one small coffee), or 200 mg (two coffees). Students then complete the same 1:00pm alertness test and a self-reported alertness rating. The clinic reports a clear dose-response pattern: average afternoon alertness scores are lowest in the 0 mg group, higher in the 100 mg group, and highest in the 200 mg group. The clinic also notes a plausible mechanism: caffeine blocks adenosine receptors and reduces perceived sleepiness in the hours after consumption.
claim: Higher morning caffeine dose increases afternoon alertness among graduate students during finals week.
label: YES

X.name: Morning caffeine dose (0mg vs 100mg vs 200mg; assigned)

causal_structure: Dose is assigned and Y shows a monotone gradient; the mechanism (adenosine blockade) provides a plausible pathway. Contextual variation in sleep deprivation affects Y but should not systematically track assigned dose.
key_insight: Mechanism + monotone dose-response is strong evidence consistent with a causal effect.
hidden_timestamp: Do the results show a consistent dose-response (0mg < 100mg < 200mg) and is a plausible mechanism described linking caffeine to alertness?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If alertness increases monotonically with assigned dose and the mechanism is plausible, the causal claim is supported (YES).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If there is no dose-response (or the pattern is inconsistent) or the assignment/mechanism is not credible, the evidence does not support the causal claim (NO).

wise_refusal: Supported: students were assigned to different caffeine doses, a clear monotone dose-response in alertness is reported, and a plausible mechanism is provided, all consistent with higher caffeine dose increasing alertness.
gold_rationale: S5 evidence: assignment plus dose-response gradient and mechanism jointly support the causal claim.

scenario: A news article compares two cities and reports that the city with a higher number of public parks per capita also has a lower average stress score among residents, based on a citywide wellness survey. The article then concludes that, for individual residents, living near more parks is associated with lower personal stress. The report provides only city-level averages (parks per capita and average stress) and does not include any resident-level data about who lives near parks or their personal stress.
claim: Living near more parks reduces an individual's personal stress.
label: NO

Z: Evidence is only city-level averages (parks per capita and average stress)

trap.subtype_name: Using aggregate correlation to claim individual effect

causal_structure: The evidence is aggregate (city-level) while the claim is individual-level. City-level correlations do not identify individual-level causal effects.
key_insight: You can’t infer an individual causal effect from group averages.
hidden_timestamp: Is the evidence only aggregate (city-level) while the claim is about individual residents?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If resident-level data showed individuals with greater park proximity have lower stress (within comparable contexts), the claim could be evaluated (AMBIGUOUS here because such data are absent).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the evidence remains only city-level averages while asserting an individual-level effect, this is an ecological fallacy and the claim is not supported (NO).

wise_refusal: No: the article uses only city-level averages but makes an individual-level causal claim. Inferring an individual effect from aggregate correlations is an ecological fallacy.
gold_rationale: W5 ecological fallacy: aggregate correlation does not establish an individual-level causal effect, so the claim is not supported by the described evidence.

scenario: A productivity blog analyzes only employees who stayed at the company for at least two years. In this “2+ year survivors” group, the blog reports that employees who frequently take on high-visibility projects also tend to have higher job satisfaction scores. The blog does not include employees who left the company within two years and does not report whether leavers differed in satisfaction or project assignments.
claim: Taking on high-visibility projects increases job satisfaction among employees.
label: NO

Z: Selection into the analysis (only employees who remained employed for 2+ years)

trap.subtype_name: Analysis excludes those who left (failures missing)

causal_structure: Conditioning on being employed 2+ years selects on survival/retention; if leaving relates to satisfaction and/or project assignment, the observed survivor-only relationship can be distorted.
key_insight: Survivors can look different from the full population, creating misleading causal stories.
hidden_timestamp: Does the analysis exclude employees who left within two years (i.e., does it observe only 'survivors')?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the analysis included both stayers and leavers and measured projects before (and satisfaction after), the claim could be evaluated (AMBIGUOUS because those data are absent).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Given only 2+ year survivors are analyzed while the claim is about all employees, survivorship bias can distort the relationship, so the causal claim is not supported (NO).

wise_refusal: No: the blog analyzes only employees who stayed at least two years. Excluding leavers can distort the projects–satisfaction relationship, so the survivor-only evidence does not support the causal claim for all employees.
gold_rationale: W2 survivorship bias: selection on retention can bias the observed relationship, making the causal claim unsupported by the described analysis.

scenario: A community health newsletter surveys people who choose to attend a weekly “wellness walk” group. The survey reports that attendees who regularly go on the wellness walk tend to have lower resting heart rate than adults in the neighborhood who do not attend. The newsletter does not account for the fact that many attendees also report exercising outside the group and following healthier diets, and participation is voluntary.
claim: Participating in the weekly wellness walk group reduces resting heart rate in the neighborhood.
label: NO

X.name: Participating in the weekly wellness walk group (voluntary)

Z: Diet quality / exercise outside the group

trap.subtype_name: People who choose X also do other health-promoting behaviors

causal_structure: Health-conscious traits and behaviors (Z) increase likelihood of joining the walk group (X) and also reduce resting heart rate (Y), confounding the observed association.
key_insight: Self-selection by healthier people can create a fake 'treatment effect.'
hidden_timestamp: Is participation voluntary and correlated with other healthy behaviors (diet/exercise) that also lower resting heart rate?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If participants and non-participants were comparable in baseline fitness/lifestyle (or assignment to the group were random) and attendees still had lower heart rate, the claim could be evaluated (AMBIGUOUS because that evidence is absent).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Given participation is voluntary and attendees also report healthier diets/exercise, healthy user bias can explain the pattern, so the causal claim is not supported (NO).

wise_refusal: No: participation is voluntary and likely attracts more health-conscious people who also exercise more and eat healthier, which can lower resting heart rate. That confounding (healthy user bias) means the evidence does not support the causal claim.
gold_rationale: W3 healthy user bias: self-selection into the program is correlated with other health behaviors that affect heart rate, so the causal claim is not supported by the described comparison.

scenario: An office introduces a “no screens after 10 PM” sleep-hygiene tip for employees. The following week, employees report sleeping better than the week before. No control group is used, and the comparison is simply before vs after the tip was announced.
claim: Adopting a no-screens-after-10-PM rule causes office employees to sleep better.
label: AMBIGUOUS

Z: Time trends / seasonality (e.g., workload changes across weeks)
Regression to the mean / novelty effect

trap.subtype_name: Pre-post comparison without a control group

causal_structure: A simple pre-post change in Y after introducing X can reflect time-varying factors (Z) rather than X causing Y, so causal support is weak without a control group.
key_insight: Before-after changes can be driven by trends or unrelated changes unless there’s a credible control.
hidden_timestamp: Is there any contemporaneous control group (or stable baseline) to separate the effect of the tip from week-to-week variation?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If a comparable control group (not exposed to the tip) shows no improvement while the exposed group improves, the claim would be more supported (still depends on comparability).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If this is only a before-after comparison with no control and other week-to-week changes are plausible, the causal claim remains AMBIGUOUS.

wise_refusal: Ambiguous: the evidence is a simple before-after comparison without a control group, so the improvement could be due to time trends, workload shifts, or a novelty effect rather than the no-screens rule itself.
gold_rationale: This matches a before-after setup without a proper control; observed changes in sleep quality cannot be cleanly attributed to the intervention because plausible time-varying confounders remain.

scenario: A city’s subway line unexpectedly shuts down for two weeks due to emergency repairs, forcing many commuters to bike or walk instead. A workplace health survey run immediately before and immediately after the shutdown finds average daily step counts increased during the shutdown period among employees who previously relied on that line, compared to employees who were not affected by the shutdown.
claim: Forcing commuters to bike or walk instead of taking the subway increases daily step counts.
label: YES

X.name: Commuting by bike/walk due to unexpected subway shutdown

Z: Weather differences across the two survey windows
Temporary schedule changes during the shutdown (work-from-home policies)

trap.subtype_name: Externally imposed change creates a quasi-experimental contrast

causal_structure: An unexpected transit shutdown plausibly shifts commuting mode (X) for affected commuters but not unaffected commuters, supporting a quasi-experimental comparison for Y if other factors (Z) are not driving the change.
key_insight: A sudden external shock can create a credible comparison group when it shifts X for some people but not others.
hidden_timestamp: Was the subway shutdown unexpected and did it differentially affect the commuting mode of one group while leaving a comparable group unaffected?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the shutdown was unexpected, affected and unaffected employees are otherwise comparable, and step counts rose mainly for the affected group during the shutdown, the causal claim is supported (YES).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If affected employees also changed work arrangements (e.g., more WFH) or measurement windows differ in weather/activity in ways not comparable, the claim becomes AMBIGUOUS.

wise_refusal: Supported conditional on comparability: an unexpected shutdown plausibly forced a commuting-mode change for one group and not another; if the groups and measurement windows are comparable, the pattern supports a causal effect of switching to bike/walk on steps.
gold_rationale: This is a natural-experiment style design: an external, plausibly exogenous disruption shifts X for a subset, enabling a quasi-experimental contrast in Y against an unaffected comparison group.

scenario: A company analyzes only employees who both volunteered for an optional mentorship program and also received at least one promotion in the last year. Within this restricted group, employees who worked fewer hours appear to have higher performance ratings. The analysis excludes employees who did not volunteer or were not promoted.
claim: Working fewer hours causes employees to have higher performance ratings.
label: NO

Z: Conditioning on a selected group defined by mentorship volunteering AND promotion (collider/selection)

trap.subtype_name: Restricting to a group defined by two causes induces spurious associations

causal_structure: Mentorship volunteering and promotion can both be influenced by unobserved traits that also affect hours and performance; conditioning on the joint-selected group can induce a spurious X–Y association.
key_insight: Conditioning on a collider can flip or create relationships that aren’t causal.
hidden_timestamp: Is the reported relationship computed only after restricting to employees selected by both mentorship volunteering and promotion?
