conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the analysis were run on the full employee population (without conditioning on volunteering/promotion) and still showed the same pattern after appropriate controls, the causal claim could be assessed (AMBIGUOUS given missing evidence).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Given the relationship is computed only within a jointly selected subgroup, the association can be collider-induced and does not support the causal claim (NO).

wise_refusal: No: the analysis conditions on a highly selected subgroup (mentorship volunteers who were promoted). Conditioning on selection/colliders can induce misleading associations, so this does not justify a causal claim that fewer hours improve performance.
gold_rationale: This is collider/selection bias: restricting the sample to people who meet criteria influenced by multiple factors can generate spurious correlations between X and Y.

scenario: A meditation app reports that users who have been active for at least 90 days show larger stress reductions than new users. The report excludes users who quit the app before day 90 and does not describe stress levels for those who dropped out.
claim: Using the meditation app causes users to reduce stress.
label: NO

Z: Survivorship/retention: analysis includes only users who remain active for 90 days
Self-selection: more motivated or less stressed users may persist

trap.subtype_name: Only long-term users are analyzed; dropouts are excluded

causal_structure: Stress reduction among retained users can reflect who persists (Z) rather than an effect of X; excluding dropouts biases the observed association.
key_insight: If you only look at people who stayed, you may confuse persistence with effectiveness.
hidden_timestamp: Are users who quit before day 90 excluded from the analysis (and do we know how their stress changed)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If stress changes were measured for all users regardless of retention (including dropouts) and still showed reductions attributable to app use, the claim could be supported (AMBIGUOUS given missing evidence).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Given the analysis conditions on long-term active users and excludes dropouts, the evidence does not support the causal claim (NO).

wise_refusal: No: the report analyzes only users who remain active for 90 days. That survivorship/retention filter can make outcomes look better than they are and does not justify a causal claim about the app’s effect.
gold_rationale: This is survivorship bias: excluding dropouts breaks representativeness and can overstate apparent benefits, so the causal claim is not supported by the described evidence.

scenario: A survey asks people whether they “exercise regularly” and whether they “feel happier.” The survey does not define what counts as exercise or what time window “regularly” refers to, and it does not specify whether happiness is current mood or long-term wellbeing. Respondents who answer “yes” to exercising regularly also report being happier.
claim: Exercising regularly causes people to be happier.
label: AMBIGUOUS

Z: Ambiguous operationalization of X and Y
Potential confounding by baseline health or life circumstances

causal_structure: When X and Y are not operationalized, the intended causal question is ill-posed; even a reported association cannot be mapped to a clear causal claim.
key_insight: If you can’t define X and Y, you can’t evaluate causality.
hidden_timestamp: What specifically counts as “exercise regularly,” and is happiness measured after (and attributable to) exercise within a defined time window?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If X is clearly defined (e.g., ≥150 minutes/week moderate activity over the last month) and Y is measured afterward using a standard scale, the causal question is well-posed but still not established by a simple survey (AMBIGUOUS).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If X/Y remain undefined and timing is unclear, the causal claim is not well-posed and remains AMBIGUOUS.

wise_refusal: Ambiguous: the survey doesn’t define what “exercise regularly” means or what “happier” measures (and the timing is unclear). Without clear variable definitions, the causal claim can’t be evaluated.
gold_rationale: This is an ambiguity trap: undefined/underspecified variables and timing prevent a clear causal interpretation, so the claim cannot be supported or refuted from the given information.

scenario: A sleep clinic runs a randomized trial for two weeks: each night, participants are randomly assigned to either enable a blue-light filter on their phone after 9:00 PM or keep their usual phone settings. Each morning, all participants complete the same sleep quality questionnaire about the previous night. Averaged over the two weeks, nights with the blue-light filter have higher reported sleep quality than nights without it.
claim: Using a blue-light filter on a phone after 9:00 PM increases sleep quality that night.
label: YES

X.name: Blue-light filter enabled after 9:00 PM (randomized by night)

Y.name: Self-reported sleep quality the next morning

causal_structure: Because X is randomized by night within participants, systematic differences in Y between filter and no-filter nights provide experimental evidence consistent with X -> Y; Z may affect Y but should not systematically differ by X under randomization.
key_insight: Random assignment (filter vs no filter) makes confounding unlikely, so the observed difference supports the causal claim.
hidden_timestamp: Were nights randomly assigned to blue-light filter vs no filter before measuring sleep quality the next morning?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the randomized blue-light-filter nights have higher reported sleep quality than control nights, the causal claim is supported (YES).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the randomized conditions show no difference (or the filter nights are worse), this trial does not support the causal claim (NO).

wise_refusal: Supported: because phone settings were randomized by night and sleep quality was measured consistently the next morning, the higher average sleep quality on blue-light-filter nights is experimental evidence consistent with the filter improving sleep quality.
gold_rationale: This is S1 (RCT): randomized exposure and a consistent outcome measure support the causal claim given the reported improvement under the treatment condition.

scenario: Two similar apartments in the same building have comparable square footage and the same electric rate plan. For one month, Apartment A is instructed to set its thermostat to 68°F overnight, while Apartment B keeps its usual overnight temperature settings. Both apartments keep similar daytime schedules and do not change appliances. At the end of the month, Apartment A has lower overnight electricity usage than Apartment B.
claim: Lowering the thermostat overnight reduces overnight electricity usage.
label: YES

X.name: Lower thermostat setpoint overnight (68°F vs usual)

Z: Outdoor temperature variation during the month

trap.subtype_name: Change X while holding other factors constant

causal_structure: The comparison attempts to hold other factors constant (same building/rate plan/similar schedules) while changing only the overnight thermostat setting; lower usage in the ablation group supports X -> Y if the controls are credible.
key_insight: When two comparable units differ mainly in the thermostat setting, lower usage is evidence consistent with a causal effect.
hidden_timestamp: Were the apartments comparable and were other major drivers of electricity usage held similar while only the overnight thermostat setting differed?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If apartments were comparable and other usage drivers stayed similar while only the overnight thermostat setpoint differed, lower overnight usage supports the claim (YES).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If other factors differed substantially (e.g., window opening, heater use, occupancy), the observed difference could be confounded (AMBIGUOUS).

wise_refusal: Supported conditional on the stated controls: the scenario describes a controlled ablation where the main systematic difference is lowering the overnight thermostat, and the lowered-setting apartment used less overnight electricity—consistent with a causal reduction.
gold_rationale: This matches S4 (controlled ablation): X is changed while other conditions are intended to be held similar, and the observed lower Y supports the causal claim as described.

scenario: A company runs a 30-day mindfulness challenge and then analyzes only employees who completed all 30 days. Within this completer group, employees who did longer daily sessions report lower stress at day 30 than employees who did shorter sessions. The analysis excludes employees who dropped out before day 30 and does not describe how dropouts differed in stress or workload.
claim: Doing longer daily mindfulness sessions reduces employees' stress.
label: NO

Z: Selection into the analysis (only 30-day completers are included)

trap.subtype_name: Analysis excludes those who left (failures missing)

causal_structure: Conditioning on completion (a form of survival) can distort the relationship between session length and stress if completion is related to baseline stress, workload, or motivation; thus the observed within-completers association does not support a causal claim in the intended population.
key_insight: If you only look at completers, the apparent effect can be driven by who managed to finish, not by the treatment intensity.
hidden_timestamp: Does the analysis include only employees who completed the full 30-day challenge (excluding dropouts)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If both completers and non-completers were included (or dropout were properly modeled) and longer sessions still predicted lower stress, the claim could be assessed (AMBIGUOUS given those data are not provided).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Given only 30-day completers are analyzed, survivorship bias can distort the relationship, so the causal claim is not supported (NO).

wise_refusal: No: the analysis includes only employees who completed the full 30-day challenge. Excluding dropouts can bias the session-length–stress relationship, so the completer-only evidence does not justify the causal claim.
gold_rationale: W2 survivorship bias: restricting to completers (survivors) can create misleading associations, so the stated causal conclusion is not supported by the described evidence.

scenario: A manager surveys employees after a particularly stressful product launch, when many employees report feeling burned out. In the same survey, employees also report how many vacation days they took during the launch period. Employees with higher burnout report having taken more vacation days, but the survey does not indicate whether the vacation days occurred before burnout symptoms began or were taken reactively after employees already felt burned out.
claim: Taking more vacation days causes employees to feel more burned out during a stressful launch.
label: NO

X.name: Vacation days taken (measured during/after burnout symptoms)

Z: Burnout leading to reactive time off (burnout can increase vacation use)

causal_structure: If burnout symptoms begin before or drive taking vacation days (Y -> X), then the observed association can reflect reverse causation rather than X -> Y; the timing is inconsistent with the causal claim as stated.
key_insight: When the exposure is measured after (or reactive to) the outcome, the direction can be reversed.
hidden_timestamp: Were the vacation days taken primarily after burnout symptoms began (i.e., were they reactive to burnout)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If vacation days were taken after burnout symptoms began (reactively), the pattern is consistent with burnout causing time off, so the causal claim is not supported (NO).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If vacation days were scheduled and taken before burnout onset (and burnout was measured afterward), then the relationship could be evaluated (AMBIGUOUS given other confounding is not addressed).

wise_refusal: No: because vacation days may have been taken reactively after employees already felt burned out, the evidence is consistent with burnout increasing time off (reverse causation), not vacation causing burnout.
gold_rationale: W9 reverse causation: the likely temporal ordering is Y -> X, so the observed association does not support the causal claim X -> Y.

scenario: A survey asks remote workers whether they do “deep work” and whether they are “more productive.” The survey does not define what counts as deep work (e.g., uninterrupted blocks vs any focused time), does not specify the time window (today vs last week), and does not define productivity (tasks completed, quality ratings, or self-perception). The survey summary reports that respondents who say they do deep work also say they are more productive.
claim: Doing deep work increases productivity among remote workers.
label: AMBIGUOUS

X.name: Doing 'deep work' (undefined construct and time window)

Y.name: Productivity (undefined metric; self-perception vs objective output)

Z: Measurement ambiguity: X and Y are not operationalized (definition and timing unclear)

causal_structure: Because X and Y lack operational definitions and timing, the causal question is not well-posed; it is unclear what intervention or outcome measure the claim refers to.
key_insight: If X and Y are undefined, you cannot interpret or evaluate the causal claim.
hidden_timestamp: What exactly counts as 'deep work' (and over what time window), and how is 'productivity' measured (objective output vs self-report)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If X were defined as a specific intervention (e.g., two uninterrupted 60-minute blocks per day) and Y were an objective metric measured afterward, the causal question would be well-posed but not answered by this survey summary (AMBIGUOUS).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If X/Y remain undefined in meaning and timing, the causal claim is not well-posed and remains AMBIGUOUS.

wise_refusal: Ambiguous: the survey does not define 'deep work' or 'productivity' or specify timing. Without clear variable definitions, the causal claim cannot be evaluated from the reported association.
gold_rationale: This is an A (measurement ambiguity) case: key operational details for X and Y are missing, so the claim cannot be interpreted precisely and remains ambiguous.
